description: The Linux in the Cloud series focuses on implementing the Linux operating system in a virtualized environment. Companies are relying less and less on dedicated hardware and are instead turning to shared hardware to optimize resource utilization and increase deployment flexibility. The hosts demonstrate virtualizing Linux using technologies like KVM and Docker as well as public cloud deployments using Amazon EC2 and Microsoft Azure.

Don can you tell us about

5

>> Well in this series we're gonna be
taking a look at what it's like to run

6

the Linux operating system on

7
00:00:19.100 --> 00:00:21.970
A lot of people are virtualizing
environments now, either doing

8

it in private clouds or public clouds and
clinics is a big part of that.

9

For the most, it runs kind of the same
on an actual hardware verses on cloud or

10

virtualized hardware.

11

But in this series we're gonna

the things that make it a little bit

The view it as a risk,

00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:43.910
We're gonna take a look at what's involved

00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:46.990
get this up and

16
00:00:46.990 --> 00:00:49.550
>> Okay, and
who is this show targeted towards?

17
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:51.968
>> Mainly this is gonna be targeted
towards system administrators.

18
00:00:51.968 --> 00:00:55.424
If you're responsible for supporting
a Linux infrastructure, and you've got

19
00:00:55.424 --> 00:00:59.000
on-premises equipment and now you're

20
00:00:59.000 --> 00:01:02.040
Be it a private cloud with your
own virtualization servers or

21

a public cloud with Amazon,
or Microsoft, or

00:01:04.930 --> 00:01:08.810
somebody like that,
it's a little tricky to make that jump.

23
00:01:08.810 --> 00:01:10.920
And so
this is really targeted towards you.

24
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:13.740
>> So Don,
is there a certification involved in this?

25
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:15.600
>> There's a number of cloud
certifications out there, but

26
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:16.660
we're not gonna focus on that.

27
00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:19.440
We're just gonna try and
keep this as an introductory type thing,

28
00:01:19.440 --> 00:01:21.020
that's general audience.

29
00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:24.350
If you just wanna learn and be aware,
that's what this series is all about.

30
00:01:24.350 --> 00:01:28.044
So it's more focused on a technical
skill than it is a certification.

31
00:01:28.044 --> 00:01:30.039
>> And,
what topics are available in this show?

32
00:01:30.039 --> 00:01:33.520
>> Well, we're really covering
pretty much anything people ask for.

33
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:37.770
But the main ones that we're gonna cover
here initially are gonna be Linux on KVM.

34
00:01:37.770 --> 00:01:39.540
KVM is tha Kernel Virtual Machine.

35
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:43.810
It's the service that really Amazon
web services uses under the hood,

36
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:44.840
you can run it privately.

37
00:01:44.840 --> 00:01:47.044
So we'll talk about it KVM host and

38
00:01:47.044 --> 00:01:50.315
then actually run Linux as
KVM guest on top of that.

39
00:01:50.315 --> 00:01:54.112
So creating a virtualized environment
entirely off of open source KVM.

40
00:01:54.112 --> 00:01:56.107
Then we'll take a look at Amazon EC2.

41
00:01:56.107 --> 00:01:59.993
So if you're using the elastic compute
cloud and you're deploying instances,

42
00:01:59.993 --> 00:02:03.949
VM's there, we'll see what it's like to
get Linux up and running inside of AWS.

43
00:02:03.949 --> 00:02:06.065
Then we're gonna move into
the Microsoft side of thing,

44
00:02:06.065 --> 00:02:07.220
I know it's funny to say that.

45
00:02:07.220 --> 00:02:08.840
Well we're gonna talk about
Microsoft on a Linux show.

46
00:02:08.840 --> 00:02:12.424
But it's really important because
Microsoft Azure is the number two player

47
00:02:12.424 --> 00:02:16.019
in cloud services right now, they have
created a massive infrastructure.

48
00:02:16.019 --> 00:02:18.611
So we'll see how to build up
our Linux virtual machines,

49
00:02:18.611 --> 00:02:20.075
get them thrown on top of Azure.

50
00:02:20.075 --> 00:02:23.898
And even though we're using a Microsoft
service we can still say in the Linux

51
00:02:23.898 --> 00:02:26.390
world and deploy things that we want.

52
00:02:26.390 --> 00:02:30.520
And then we're also going to really
bridge the gap and talk about Docker.

53
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:34.520
Docker is a IT industry buzz word and
if you're a developer, you've

54
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:38.080
got to learn that system administrators
are largely being neglected on this.

55
00:02:38.080 --> 00:02:42.460
And so I wanna take the time to show you
guys what Docker is, how it works, and

56
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:45.570
we'll see how we can run Linux
inside of our Docker containers.

57
00:02:45.570 --> 00:02:49.340
As well as use Linux as our Docker host
to be able to power that environment and

58
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:50.570
give a chance to see that.

59
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:53.810
So these are all pretty typical
cloud type deployments, and

60
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:56.570
we're gonna walk through them,
get comfortable with it, and

61
00:02:56.570 --> 00:03:00.710
make it where we can all recognize how
we can be using Linux as a ,loud OS.

62
00:03:00.710 --> 00:03:01.340
>> Thank you, Don.

63
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:06.033
So Linux in the Cloud sounds like a show
you'd be interested in, and it should be,

64
00:03:06.033 --> 00:03:09.518
watch every single episode of
Linux in the Cloud on ITProTV.

65
00:03:09.518 --> 00:03:14.243
[MUSIC]

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.950 --> 00:00:01.986
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.986 --> 00:00:06.281
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.281 --> 00:00:08.098
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.098 --> 00:00:10.903
>> You're watching ITVProTV.

5
00:00:10.903 --> 00:00:12.045
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:12.045 --> 00:00:14.224
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

7
00:00:14.224 --> 00:00:16.490
helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:16.490 --> 00:00:20.890
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we begin with Linux in the cloud, and

9
00:00:20.890 --> 00:00:24.150
this is Linux as a KVM host,
what does that mean?

10
00:00:24.150 --> 00:00:26.390
Well, Don Pezet is here
because he's our expert, and

11
00:00:26.390 --> 00:00:28.760
he's gonna tell us exactly what
that means, aren't you, Don?

12
00:00:28.760 --> 00:00:29.350
>> Absolutely,

13
00:00:29.350 --> 00:00:33.530
so in this episode we're gonna be taking
a look at using Linux as a KVM host.

14
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:37.920
And KVM is a virtualization software
package that we can load on top of Linux

15
00:00:37.920 --> 00:00:39.080
as an operating system.

16
00:00:39.080 --> 00:00:42.170
Now this series is the Linux
in the cloud series, and

17
00:00:42.170 --> 00:00:44.980
you might be asking yourself,
how does this tie into the cloud?

18
00:00:44.980 --> 00:00:48.590
Well, what you'll find is that most of
the cloud providers that are out there,

19
00:00:48.590 --> 00:00:50.268
like Amazon with Amazon Web Services,

20
00:00:50.268 --> 00:00:54.375
their virtualization technology's
built on top of Xen.

21
00:00:54.375 --> 00:00:58.275
And Xen is actually built off of KVM,
it's a fork of KVM.

22
00:00:58.275 --> 00:01:02.405
So this technology that we're gonna
look at here is really a staple of

23
00:01:02.405 --> 00:01:06.255
virtualization technologies all across
the world, it's used everywhere.

24
00:01:06.255 --> 00:01:10.385
Well, when we set up a cloud, what we're
really talking about are virtual servers

25
00:01:10.385 --> 00:01:12.260
running in a virtualized environment.

26
00:01:12.260 --> 00:01:16.790
It doesn't have to be a public
cloud like Amazon Web Services or

27
00:01:16.790 --> 00:01:20.100
Microsoft Azure or whatever,
it can be a private cloud.

28
00:01:20.100 --> 00:01:24.580
If it's a private cloud, if you're setting
up your own cloud in your own company,

29
00:01:24.580 --> 00:01:28.340
then you don't use the AWS technologies,
you use your own.

30
00:01:28.340 --> 00:01:32.567
And if you're gonna do that,
a great way to do it is with Linux KVM.

31
00:01:32.567 --> 00:01:36.051
It's good enough for the big guys,
it's good enough for your company, so

32
00:01:36.051 --> 00:01:39.280
if we wanna deploy that,
you find that it's actually not that hard.

33
00:01:39.280 --> 00:01:44.160
That we can take just about any Linux
distribution, tack KVM on top of it, and

34
00:01:44.160 --> 00:01:47.489
all of a sudden, we've got a great
virtual machine host configured, and

35
00:01:47.489 --> 00:01:48.795
we built our own private cloud.

36
00:01:48.795 --> 00:01:49.480
So that's what

37
00:01:49.480 --> 00:01:51.550
we're gonna take a look at right here
in this episode of setting it up.

38
00:01:51.550 --> 00:01:55.230
And we'll follow it up with other episodes
on getting our guests fired up on it, and

39
00:01:55.230 --> 00:01:56.520
getting those configured.

40
00:01:56.520 --> 00:01:59.976
But on the server side, this is where we
start, we're gonna take a Linux box and

41
00:01:59.976 --> 00:02:02.556
actually get it set up to be able
to host virtual machines and

42
00:02:02.556 --> 00:02:05.470
provide that cloud infrastructure,
in our own private company.

43
00:02:05.470 --> 00:02:07.993
>> So now you've got me very excited,
and very intrigued, so

44
00:02:07.993 --> 00:02:10.931
let's find out more about KVM,
what exactly is it, how do we get it?

45
00:02:10.931 --> 00:02:14.506
>> All right, KVM, it stands for
Kernel Virtual Machine, and

46
00:02:14.506 --> 00:02:18.896
it's an extension that gets tacked
onto the kernel of your Linux distro.

47
00:02:18.896 --> 00:02:24.072
So there's a ton of distros, there's
Ubuntu, Red Hat, Fedora, and Debian.

48
00:02:24.072 --> 00:02:25.008
At the end of the day,

49
00:02:25.008 --> 00:02:28.010
though, under the hood,
they're all running the Linux kernel.

50
00:02:28.010 --> 00:02:29.984
It might be a different version
of the Linux kernel, but

51
00:02:29.984 --> 00:02:31.374
they are all running the Linux kernel.

52
00:02:31.374 --> 00:02:36.149
And there's a module we can stick
onto that kernel that allows it to

53
00:02:36.149 --> 00:02:38.580
act as a type one hypervisor.

54
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:42.508
Now, what is a type one hypervisor, a type
one hypervisor is like a traffic cop.

55
00:02:42.508 --> 00:02:46.383
It says, if you're gonna run five virtual
machines, you don't want just one virtual

56
00:02:46.383 --> 00:02:50.010
machine grabbing the CPU and holding it,
and everybody else is just out of luck.

57
00:02:50.010 --> 00:02:52.483
So a type one hypervisor kind
of acts as a gate, and it says,

58
00:02:52.483 --> 00:02:55.844
here's this virtual machine, that's
allowed to access the CPU right now, and

59
00:02:55.844 --> 00:02:58.774
as soon as it's done, then we let
machine two and then machine three.

60
00:02:58.774 --> 00:03:03.009
We kind of rotate through, so t's gating
that access, the virtual machines

61
00:03:03.009 --> 00:03:06.865
are seeing the actual hardware, so
they perform at very high speeds.

62
00:03:06.865 --> 00:03:10.561
They function really, really well because
they're seeing the real hardware, and

63
00:03:10.561 --> 00:03:13.970
the type one hypervisor is
handling that concurrent access.

64
00:03:13.970 --> 00:03:18.140
Now, not every guest OS that is
out there will support that,

65
00:03:18.140 --> 00:03:21.030
some operating systems really
just don't understand,

66
00:03:21.030 --> 00:03:23.660
they aren't able to deal with
that direct hardware access.

67
00:03:23.660 --> 00:03:27.660
And so in those scenarios, we have to
do what's called emulated hardware.

68
00:03:27.660 --> 00:03:31.540
An emulated hardware is where
they don't see the real CPU,

69
00:03:31.540 --> 00:03:36.550
they don't see the real RAM,
instead they see fake RAM and a fake CPU.

70
00:03:36.550 --> 00:03:39.510
And then the hypervisor has to take
the calls to that fake CPU and

71
00:03:39.510 --> 00:03:41.570
translate it into calls to a real CPU.

72
00:03:41.570 --> 00:03:45.550
That's called a type two hypervisor,
and type two hypervisors are slower.

73
00:03:45.550 --> 00:03:48.350
They're more compatible,
almost every OS out there will

74
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:51.777
run as a guest OS on a type two
hypervisor, but they're slower.

75
00:03:51.777 --> 00:03:57.200
So in general, type two hypervisors
are used in test and R&D environments.

76
00:03:57.200 --> 00:03:59.562
And type one hypervisors are used
in production whenever possible,

77
00:03:59.562 --> 00:04:02.100
cuz they give you the best performance and
speed.

78
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:05.400
Well, KVM is a type one hypervisor,

79
00:04:05.400 --> 00:04:08.140
it runs these virtual
machines at near meta speeds.

80
00:04:08.140 --> 00:04:11.345
It does a really good job of it, and
it's completely free, it's open source.

81
00:04:11.345 --> 00:04:14.190
It's baked right in to most Linux distros,
or we can install it really,

82
00:04:14.190 --> 00:04:18.194
really easy, and get it put in place,
and now we're doing that.

83
00:04:18.194 --> 00:04:23.476
But KVM is normally packaged with
another product, a product called QEMU.

84
00:04:23.476 --> 00:04:26.307
QEMU stands for Quick Emulator, and

85
00:04:26.307 --> 00:04:31.610
Quick Emulator is a little program
that is a type two hypervisor.

86
00:04:31.610 --> 00:04:36.580
It handles emulating hardware,
creating fake hardware, and by doing that,

87
00:04:36.580 --> 00:04:39.340
it allows us to support guests that
wouldn't normally run on top of KVM.

88
00:04:39.340 --> 00:04:42.310
So when you install one,
you're normally installing both, so

89
00:04:42.310 --> 00:04:43.880
I wanted to mention that
here in the beginning,

90
00:04:43.880 --> 00:04:47.150
cuz we're gonna see QEMU pop up
a few times throughout the show.

91
00:04:47.150 --> 00:04:51.060
But know that everything that
I'm doing is really intended to

92
00:04:51.060 --> 00:04:54.440
be done on the KVM side, it just
happens that QEMU comes along with it.

93
00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:58.060
And so when configured properly,
you'll be using KVM for everything,

94
00:04:58.060 --> 00:04:59.800
and QEMU just kinda sits there.

95
00:04:59.800 --> 00:05:03.515
But there are times when QEMU still gets
used, like with network card drivers,

96
00:05:03.515 --> 00:05:06.343
gets used a lot to help create
the virtual network adapters so

97
00:05:06.343 --> 00:05:08.237
that all the traffic is isolated right.

98
00:05:08.237 --> 00:05:11.914
QEMU actually does a better job
with that than KVM does, and so

99
00:05:11.914 --> 00:05:16.120
it'll take over that role, and
the two really work hand in hand.

100
00:05:16.120 --> 00:05:20.520
So we're not just installing KVM,
we're installing KVM and QEMU together,

101
00:05:20.520 --> 00:05:24.170
putting them on our system, and they
get in there and they take care of it.

102
00:05:24.170 --> 00:05:27.863
So as long as we've got hardware that
supports it, we can install this, and

103
00:05:27.863 --> 00:05:31.692
now we've got a KVM host up and going,
and we're creating our private cloud.

104
00:05:31.692 --> 00:05:34.636
>> So
how do we know if our system supports KVM?

105
00:05:34.636 --> 00:05:39.350
>> Well, most hardware today does, so
if you go and you buy a server from HP or

106
00:05:39.350 --> 00:05:41.722
Dell, or you build your own server.

107
00:05:41.722 --> 00:05:45.535
Plenty of people white box it, and not
little people, like Facebook and Google,

108
00:05:45.535 --> 00:05:46.981
they build their own servers.

109
00:05:46.981 --> 00:05:50.728
You can certainly do that, and
the odds are, you'll just luck out, and

110
00:05:50.728 --> 00:05:52.762
it will support full virtualization.

111
00:05:52.762 --> 00:05:55.980
But type one hypervisors,
the way they function is,

112
00:05:55.980 --> 00:06:01.070
they rely on these virtualization
extensions that are built into the CPU.

113
00:06:01.070 --> 00:06:05.069
So when you get that Intel CPU,
like a i7 or a Xeon,

114
00:06:05.069 --> 00:06:09.174
or you get an AMD CPU,
because somebody buys those.

115
00:06:09.174 --> 00:06:10.754
>> [LAUGH]
>> When you get those,

116
00:06:10.754 --> 00:06:14.070
then you normally see-
>> And that's another story.

117
00:06:14.070 --> 00:06:16.708
>> We don't typically see AMD in
the server market, you normally see

118
00:06:16.708 --> 00:06:20.070
it in the workstation market, and we're
not usually running KVM on a workstation.

119
00:06:20.070 --> 00:06:24.323
You certainly can, though, so
if you've got an AMD CPU in your laptop,

120
00:06:24.323 --> 00:06:26.642
you probably still could run KVM on it.

121
00:06:26.642 --> 00:06:29.525
But you need to make sure it's got
the virtualization extensions.

122
00:06:29.525 --> 00:06:34.110
Now, the easiest way to do that is
if you know what processor you have,

123
00:06:34.110 --> 00:06:35.990
like I've got an Intel i7.

124
00:06:35.990 --> 00:06:39.519
If I know the model number, I can just go
to Intel's website and look it up, and

125
00:06:39.519 --> 00:06:40.762
it'll tell me if it has it.

126
00:06:40.762 --> 00:06:43.597
Or if I have an AMD processor,
I can go to AMD's website and look it up,

127
00:06:43.597 --> 00:06:45.860
and it'll tell me if its got that feature.

128
00:06:45.860 --> 00:06:49.500
The only problem with that method,
it's thorough, it certainly works, but

129
00:06:49.500 --> 00:06:51.180
the problem is, a lot of times,

130
00:06:51.180 --> 00:06:54.730
you can disable the virtualization
technologies in the BIOS in your system.

131
00:06:54.730 --> 00:06:56.653
So, if it's turned off in BIOS,

132
00:06:56.653 --> 00:07:01.790
then it doesn't matter if the processor
supports it or not, I'm not gonna see it.

133
00:07:01.790 --> 00:07:05.530
So I need to know, one,
that I have the features, and

134
00:07:05.530 --> 00:07:07.530
two, that they're turned on in my BIOS.

135
00:07:07.530 --> 00:07:10.120
And so instead of going to the vendor
website, I don't normally do that,

136
00:07:10.120 --> 00:07:12.980
I normally just look at what
Linux is detecting on my system.

137
00:07:12.980 --> 00:07:16.860
So we'll use my laptop here as
the example, and on my laptop,

138
00:07:16.860 --> 00:07:19.550
I've got a an Intel i7, but it's a laptop.

139
00:07:19.550 --> 00:07:23.760
So it's a mobile processor,
not necessarily a full desktop CPU,

140
00:07:23.760 --> 00:07:26.900
so do I know if I have those
virtualization extensions?

141
00:07:26.900 --> 00:07:29.896
Well, again,
I can look it up on Intel's website, or

142
00:07:29.896 --> 00:07:33.624
I can drop to the command prompt and
I can look for these extensions.

143
00:07:33.624 --> 00:07:37.858
Now, the extensions have different names,
there's the AMD ones,

00:29:07.210 --> 00:29:09.740
I don't have unlimited time here or
I would.

594
00:29:09.740 --> 00:29:11.130
But we could go more advanced and

595
00:29:11.130 --> 00:29:13.130
set up a true bridge,
where we didn't even route it.

596
00:29:13.130 --> 00:29:16.160
Where we just say, we're gonna give
you a real IP on the real network and

597
00:29:16.160 --> 00:29:19.590
you'll communicate just like any other
server, and get that kind of put in place.

598
00:29:19.590 --> 00:29:23.240
But we need to get this network stuff
set up, because once it's done,

599
00:29:23.240 --> 00:29:26.800
then as we add the virtual machines we can
get them attached to the right network.

600
00:29:26.800 --> 00:29:30.236
If I just jumped in and started creating
virtual machines, they'd all go into this

601
00:29:30.236 --> 00:29:32.805
NAT'd network and I'd have to
come back and edit it later on.

602
00:29:32.805 --> 00:29:36.826
So I always start with configuring
networks, and get them, and

603
00:29:36.826 --> 00:29:38.030
put them in place.

604
00:29:38.030 --> 00:29:40.496
>> So Don, my question to you is
are we gonna need a second part?

605
00:29:40.496 --> 00:29:41.358
>> [LAUGH]
>> You think,

606
00:29:41.358 --> 00:29:42.404
are we gonna come back a revisit this?

607
00:29:42.404 --> 00:29:43.401
>> Yeah, I think so.

608
00:29:43.401 --> 00:29:45.232
I have a lot more that I wanna talk about.

609
00:29:45.232 --> 00:29:46.111
>> Yeah, I think so.

610
00:29:46.111 --> 00:29:48.180
>> Yeah, I get a little carried away,
but there are a lot of settings in here.

611
00:29:48.180 --> 00:29:51.201
There's more stuff that we need to
configure before we start creating

612
00:29:51.201 --> 00:29:52.742
VMs to get our server ready to rock.

613
00:29:52.742 --> 00:29:55.630
So let's come back in a part two,
cuz we needed to talk about storage.

614
00:29:55.630 --> 00:29:56.700
That's pretty important thing.

615
00:29:56.700 --> 00:29:58.980
>> Right.
>> So we'll get the chance to see that in

616
00:29:58.980 --> 00:30:01.900
networks, and
kind of wrap that little bit up.

617
00:30:01.900 --> 00:30:03.533
And then after that, we'll jump in and

618
00:30:03.533 --> 00:30:06.417
actually start to create some of our
guests and put them in place too.

619
00:30:06.417 --> 00:30:09.810
So definitely stay tune for part two, and
we'll wrap up our server configuration.

620
00:30:09.810 --> 00:30:10.443
>> I'm excited on that one.

621
00:30:10.443 --> 00:30:14.160
We'll get to Linux is a KVM host part two,
you've seen part one.

622
00:30:14.160 --> 00:30:18.286
And this is Linux in the cloud, and
this is gonna continue on with the series.

623
00:30:18.286 --> 00:30:21.670
Make sure you watch all of the episodes,
you'll be glad you did.

624
00:30:21.670 --> 00:30:23.373
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

625
00:30:23.373 --> 00:30:26.310
Remember, a good IT Pro
is always learning.

626
00:30:26.310 --> 00:30:27.230
I'm Zach Memos.

627
00:30:27.230 --> 00:30:27.803
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

628
00:30:27.803 --> 00:30:28.950
>> And we'll see you again soon.

629
00:30:28.950 --> 00:30:36.515
[MUSIC]

630
00:30:36.515 --> 00:30:39.128
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss storage issues & if storage needs to be configured, KVM Storage Pools, default storage pool, Custom Storage Pools, basic setup of the server, and starting to create virtual machines.
episodes.title: Linux as a KVM Host Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.150 --> 00:00:02.704
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm you host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.704 --> 00:00:06.577
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.577 --> 00:00:08.347
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.347 --> 00:00:12.126
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.126 --> 00:00:14.600
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITPro.TV,

6
00:00:14.600 --> 00:00:17.090
helping you learn everywhere you go.

7
00:00:17.090 --> 00:00:20.770
I'm Zach Memos, your host for
the Linux in the Cloud.

8
00:00:20.770 --> 00:00:24.920
And right now we have part 2
of the Linus as a KVM host.

9
00:00:24.920 --> 00:00:26.990
Excited of hearing more about it?

10
00:00:26.990 --> 00:00:30.220
I am, and
Don Pezet is gonna tell us all about that.

11
00:00:30.220 --> 00:00:33.980
>> All right, we are picking back up
with configuring KVM on our host.

12
00:00:33.980 --> 00:00:35.499
And if you watched the last episode,

13
00:00:35.499 --> 00:00:38.390
we were covering the first things we
need to do to get our server set up.

14
00:00:38.390 --> 00:00:41.178
So we installed KVM, and
then we went to my workstation,

15
00:00:41.178 --> 00:00:43.690
I installed the GUI to manage it,
virt-manager.

16
00:00:43.690 --> 00:00:45.712
>> Yes.
>> We fire up virt-manager, and

17
00:00:45.712 --> 00:00:48.557
we can configure some basic
virtual networks, right?

18
00:00:48.557 --> 00:00:50.380
The networks that our machines will use.

19
00:00:50.380 --> 00:00:53.010
Well our machines are gonna use other
things as well, they're gonna use CPU,

20
00:00:53.010 --> 00:00:54.220
they're gonna use RAM.

21
00:00:54.220 --> 00:00:56.860
Well those are configured on the virtual
machine, not a big deal there.

22
00:00:56.860 --> 00:00:58.534
They're also gonna use storage, and

23
00:00:58.534 --> 00:01:01.210
storage is something that I
wanted to spend a few minutes on.

24
00:01:01.210 --> 00:01:04.110
Because they are variations in
the way that the storage gets

25
00:01:04.110 --> 00:01:06.430
handled inside of our virtual machines.

26
00:01:06.430 --> 00:01:08.683
So that's gonna be the next thing
that we need to get configured and

27
00:01:08.683 --> 00:01:10.710
what we're gonna take a look
at right here in this episode.

28
00:01:10.710 --> 00:01:12.520
>> Which was my next question,
what about storage?

29
00:01:12.520 --> 00:01:13.710
Do we need to configure it?

30
00:01:13.710 --> 00:01:17.217
>> Absolutely, well I guess technically,
you don't need to configure it,

31
00:01:17.217 --> 00:01:19.400
you could just run with the defaults,
right?

32
00:01:19.400 --> 00:01:22.910
But the defaults are not necessarily
ideal, let me show you what I mean.

33
00:01:22.910 --> 00:01:26.190
So on my machine,
this is where we installed KVM,

34
00:01:26.190 --> 00:01:28.308
it's on my regular old laptop.

35
00:01:28.308 --> 00:01:31.630
And when I start creating virtual
machines, where is it going to put them?

36
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:37.276
Well by default it puts them
in /var/lib/libvirt/images

37
00:01:37.276 --> 00:01:43.378
that folder right there,
that's where's gonna drop them.

38
00:01:43.378 --> 00:01:48.136
Now if /var is on the same partition
as the rest of your drive,

39
00:01:48.136 --> 00:01:52.080
then virtual machine files
they can get kinda big.

40
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:53.913
They just take up a lot of space.

41
00:01:53.913 --> 00:01:54.473
>> Yep.

42
00:01:54.473 --> 00:01:57.747
>> And eventually you can run
out of disk space, right?

43
00:01:57.747 --> 00:02:02.910
So here I am in /var if I do a df-h and
take a look at my disks.

44
00:02:02.910 --> 00:02:08.000
/var for me is not broken out
into a separate partition.

45
00:02:08.000 --> 00:02:12.070
So that means that it's just
under the root mount point, and

46
00:02:12.070 --> 00:02:15.770
if I look at my root mount point, I've
only got 42 gigs of space on it, right?

47
00:02:15.770 --> 00:02:21.070
That's not a ton of space, if I look at my
other disks, like I've got /mount/storage.

48
00:02:21.070 --> 00:02:23.870
This guy right here,
that's a terabyte drive.

49
00:02:23.870 --> 00:02:26.396
And I've got 665 gigs of
space available on it,

50
00:02:26.396 --> 00:02:28.824
I've got a ton of space
available on that drive.

51
00:02:28.824 --> 00:02:33.310
Or even /Home for that matter,
I've got 155 gigs available on that one,

52
00:02:33.310 --> 00:02:35.840
I've got space out there, right?

53
00:02:35.840 --> 00:02:41.000
Just not in /var, so
I need to think about my storage.

54
00:02:41.000 --> 00:02:45.143
If I know I'm gonna be storing
a lot of virtual machine disks,

55
00:02:45.143 --> 00:02:50.180
I may need to move /var/lib/libvirt
to a different partition, right?

56
00:02:50.180 --> 00:02:53.400
And move it somewhere else, or
it might even be on an external SAN.

57
00:02:53.400 --> 00:02:56.220
I might have some kind of scuzzy or
iscuzzy or

58
00:02:56.220 --> 00:02:59.880
fiber channel connection that's running
to a SAN where that storage is found.

59
00:02:59.880 --> 00:03:02.573
But either way only to
move it to somewhere else,

60
00:03:02.573 --> 00:03:04.880
well we never actually move the default.

61
00:03:04.880 --> 00:03:06.839
The default stays where it is,
we just choose whether or

62
00:03:06.839 --> 00:03:08.450
not we're gonna use that default.

63
00:03:08.450 --> 00:03:12.098
I might not want to use
/var/lib/libvirt/images,

64
00:03:12.098 --> 00:03:14.820
I don't wanna specify other locations.

65
00:03:14.820 --> 00:03:17.760
And then we can pick and choose,
we can use whatever we want, right?

66
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:20.870
So we got couple of options how we wanna
handle this kind of comes down to what

67
00:03:20.870 --> 00:03:22.060
our needs are.

68
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:28.630
For me, I know that /mount/storage has a
ton of space and I wanna use that, right?

69
00:03:28.630 --> 00:03:31.690
I don't want to use the default
where I don't have a ton of space.

70
00:03:31.690 --> 00:03:34.060
So I wanna modify that and change it.

71
00:03:34.060 --> 00:03:37.314
And we can do that right through the
graphical utility that we were using at

72
00:03:37.314 --> 00:03:38.950
the end of the last episode, right?

73
00:03:38.950 --> 00:03:41.253
So what you do is you go
in your virt-manager and

74
00:03:41.253 --> 00:03:43.680
you choose the server
that you're working with.

75
00:03:43.680 --> 00:03:45.370
So mine is this Don's laptop.

76
00:03:45.370 --> 00:03:47.839
And we're gonna go to Edit
> Connection Details and

77
00:03:47.839 --> 00:03:51.010
the in the last episode we were
on this Virtual Networks tab.

78
00:03:51.010 --> 00:03:56.101
This time we're gonna go to the Storage
tab and what you're gonna see in there

79
00:03:56.101 --> 00:04:01.757
is one storage location by default and
it is in /val/lb/libval/images, right?

80
00:04:01.757 --> 00:04:03.177
That's where it's located, all right?

81
00:04:03.177 --> 00:04:07.248
And it's telling me that it's got
41 gigs there is 8.5 gigs in use,

82
00:04:07.248 --> 00:04:10.150
it's Active and it's turned down On Boot.

83
00:04:10.150 --> 00:04:12.160
And then in the volumes list
here I can see it's empty.

84
00:04:12.160 --> 00:04:15.900
I have no virtual machine volumes
created in that storage just yet.

85
00:04:15.900 --> 00:04:19.810
So if I wanna change this,
I've got two choices.

86
00:04:19.810 --> 00:04:22.080
One, I can change the default, okay?

87
00:04:22.080 --> 00:04:25.855
Now the default you'll notice,
maybe you can't really tell here,

88
00:04:25.855 --> 00:04:27.100
I can't delete this.

89
00:04:27.100 --> 00:04:30.171
It won't let me edit that entry,
it won't let me change it, okay?

90
00:04:30.171 --> 00:04:33.015
I don't know what that is
it just won't let you.

91
00:04:33.015 --> 00:04:35.771
So [LAUGH] if you wanna change
the default what you have to do is,

92
00:04:35.771 --> 00:04:40.100
you have to take the default and then down
here, you need to get the Stop button.

93
00:04:40.100 --> 00:04:42.070
This little storage directories are,

94
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:45.900
actually what are cold
storage pools inside of KVM.

95
00:04:45.900 --> 00:04:47.400
Sorry, my zoom is going nuts there.

96
00:04:47.400 --> 00:04:49.010
They're called storage pools.

97
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:52.531
I define a storage pool and
when KVM starts up, when it boots,

98
00:04:52.531 --> 00:04:56.280
it indexes the storage pools
to figure out what's in them.

99
00:04:56.280 --> 00:04:59.050
So the first storage pool,
I have is just called default and

100
00:04:59.050 --> 00:05:00.510
that's where its location is.

101
00:05:00.510 --> 00:05:03.940
And because it's mounted,
it won't let me change it.

102
00:05:03.940 --> 00:05:06.240
But even if I unmount it,
like when I hit that Stop and

103
00:05:06.240 --> 00:05:08.990
I Stop the pool,
I still can't change that value.

104
00:05:08.990 --> 00:05:12.452
So if I wanna change the default, what I
need to do is take that and delete it.

105
00:05:12.452 --> 00:05:17.379
I'm gonna hit the little x, delete pool
button, and i'll delete that pool,

106
00:05:17.379 --> 00:05:19.630
and so that's gonna wipe that out.

107
00:05:19.630 --> 00:05:21.498
Now it doesn't actually
delete what's on disk,

108
00:05:21.498 --> 00:05:24.180
so if I had a bunch of virtual
machine images, they'd still be there.

109
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:27.890
I'm just deleting the pool
from KVM's configuration.

110
00:05:27.890 --> 00:05:32.165
And now I can add a new pool, and
if I want this to be the default pool,

111
00:05:32.165 --> 00:05:34.340
I need to name it default, right.

112
00:05:34.340 --> 00:05:37.320
If I don't do that, if I don't name it
default, the next time KVM starts it's

113
00:05:37.320 --> 00:05:39.960
just going to recreate that default
pool again and put it back again.

114
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:42.512
And say you deleted the pool,
what's wrong with you?

115
00:05:42.512 --> 00:05:43.930
I will just put it right back, right?

116
00:05:43.930 --> 00:05:48.530
But if I name this one default, I can
then point it to somewhere else, right?

117
00:05:48.530 --> 00:05:51.446
Now, I'll be honest with you guys,
I don't normally do this,

118
00:05:51.446 --> 00:05:53.120
I don't normally delete a default.

119
00:05:53.120 --> 00:05:56.830
I just leave it, and I add my pools,
secondary pools, right?

120
00:05:56.830 --> 00:06:00.974
And I do that for consistency reason,
I always worry, if somebody forgets to

121
00:06:00.974 --> 00:06:05.320
change the location on a KVM host,
and I just assume it's been moved.

122
00:06:05.320 --> 00:06:08.020
I would know, because it's called default,
and that's it.

123
00:06:08.020 --> 00:06:11.330
But if I give it a custom name
that I know it's been moved,

124
00:06:11.330 --> 00:06:12.710
I know it's in the right location.

125
00:06:12.710 --> 00:06:15.220
So I'm in a habit to just
leaving the default alone.

126
00:06:15.220 --> 00:06:18.840
But you certainly can modify and
put it wherever.

127
00:06:18.840 --> 00:06:23.400
I'm gonna change this one, and
I'm gonna call it MNT-Storage, right?

128
00:06:23.400 --> 00:06:28.170
Cuz I wanna know this one's in
my mount/storage folder, right?

129
00:06:28.170 --> 00:06:30.900
Now, when we go to create the pool,
it's asking us a question.

130
00:06:30.900 --> 00:06:33.570
What type of pool is this going to be?

131
00:06:33.570 --> 00:06:39.330
And if you drop that box down, you'll
see there's quite a few choices, okay?

132
00:06:39.330 --> 00:06:41.970
Well most of these are not
used that commonly, right?

133
00:06:41.970 --> 00:06:43.460
So there are some of these
that are really important.

134
00:06:43.460 --> 00:06:45.870
The very first two are probably
the most important.

135
00:06:45.870 --> 00:06:50.160
The first one is the most common,
dir Filesystem Directory, right?

136
00:06:50.160 --> 00:06:53.490
I want to store data in a directory
somehwere on my system.

137
00:06:53.490 --> 00:06:56.250
So I'm gonna point to that directory and
that's that, right?

138
00:06:56.250 --> 00:07:01.700
But it could be that I'm wanting to
expose an actual physical disk, right?

139
00:07:01.700 --> 00:07:05.918
Let's say that I was setting up
a database server like MySQL or MariaDB,

140
00:07:05.918 --> 00:07:08.210
disk I/O is really important to them.

141
00:07:08.210 --> 00:07:10.008
So I don't want QEMU to come in and

142
00:07:10.008 --> 00:07:13.560
create a virtual disk image that
I know is gonna create overhead.

143
00:07:13.560 --> 00:07:17.390
Instead, I want them to have true
unfettered access to a real disk.

144
00:07:17.390 --> 00:07:18.540
I could choose physical disk, and

145
00:07:18.540 --> 00:07:21.940
on the next screen, it'll have me pick
which physical disk is gonna be attached.

146
00:07:21.940 --> 00:07:23.880
It's gonna be locked down to one VM, but

147
00:07:23.880 --> 00:07:25.179
you'll get some great
performance out of it.

148
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:29.209
Normally, we don't do that,
normally it's a directory or

149
00:07:29.209 --> 00:07:32.070
if you as you look down you'll
find there's an LVM Volume Group.

150
00:07:32.070 --> 00:07:36.221
So we can link the Logical Volume Manager,
we can do iSCSI Targets or GlusterFS.

151
00:07:36.221 --> 00:07:39.751
GlusterFS is a cluster file system that
can spread across more than one server,

152
00:07:39.751 --> 00:07:41.608
that's great if you want to do fail over.

153
00:07:41.608 --> 00:07:43.822
I have a virtual machine,
it's running on one server right now, and

154
00:07:43.822 --> 00:07:46.110
I have a problem, so
I move it to another virtual machine.

155
00:07:46.110 --> 00:07:48.250
If that's a shared file system,
there's not much to move.

156
00:07:48.250 --> 00:07:50.977
I just shut it down on one server and
start it up on another.

157
00:07:50.977 --> 00:07:53.765
And I'm in business all the file
systems already brought along,

158
00:07:53.765 --> 00:07:55.420
cluster fs will do that for us.

159
00:07:55.420 --> 00:07:57.110
Some of the other ones will do the same.

160
00:07:57.110 --> 00:08:00.690
ZFS, very powerful but
not supported on most Linux distros.

161
00:08:00.690 --> 00:08:01.792
Sheepdog, I've never even heard

162
00:08:01.792 --> 00:08:03.160
of that one it's just there and-
>> [LAUGH]

163
00:08:03.160 --> 00:08:04.294
>> It's got a silly name,

164
00:08:04.294 --> 00:08:07.840
so take it with a grain of salt,
not all these are the greatest.

165
00:08:07.840 --> 00:08:08.656
My apologies to Sheepdog,

166
00:08:08.656 --> 00:08:09.906
might be the most awesome-
>> Yeah, [INAUDIBLE] you never know.

167
00:08:09.906 --> 00:08:11.287
>> File system on the planet,
I've never heard of it.

168
00:08:11.287 --> 00:08:15.060
So you've got a lot of choices here,
but really that first one.

169
00:08:15.060 --> 00:08:17.700
Dir, that's the one we're
gonna be using the most.

170
00:08:17.700 --> 00:08:20.528
And I'm telling it that I'm gonna
point to a directory somewhere.

171
00:08:20.528 --> 00:08:26.550
And as I move forward, it's going to ask
me, oops, it's gonna ask me where, right?

172
00:08:26.550 --> 00:08:28.099
And see what it is trying to do,

173
00:08:28.099 --> 00:08:31.870
it's trying to create a subfolder
under /val/lib/libvirt/images.

174
00:08:31.870 --> 00:08:34.520
And that's not what I want,
I wanna put it somewhere else entirely.

175
00:08:34.520 --> 00:08:38.254
So I'm gonna browse, and I'll browse
across my file system and go and

176
00:08:38.254 --> 00:08:40.670
find a folder that I wanna stick in it.

177
00:08:40.670 --> 00:08:44.320
And maybe the folder exist already,
maybe it doesn't, I'll add a new folder.

178
00:08:44.320 --> 00:08:46.090
And I'm gonna call this,

179
00:08:46.090 --> 00:08:50.522
I'll call it qmu-kvm that's
where we're storing it's data.

180
00:08:50.522 --> 00:08:54.130
So I've got this new folder and
I'll go ahead and

181
00:08:54.130 --> 00:08:56.696
hit the open button, there we go.

182

00:25:36.490 --> 00:25:39.710
Now if I was in a hurry, I could just
hit Review and Launch and I'm done.

548
00:25:39.710 --> 00:25:42.640
But let me walk you through some of
the menu choices here that we've got.

549
00:25:42.640 --> 00:25:47.520
As I start to move forward its gonna
ask me, how many instances do I want?

550
00:25:47.520 --> 00:25:48.540
I'm about to launch a Red Hat server.

551
00:25:48.540 --> 00:25:49.610
Do I want one?

552
00:25:49.610 --> 00:25:53.414
Or do I want 1,000?
Let me just, 1,000, right?

553
00:25:53.414 --> 00:25:56.153
Now if you just signed up for
an AWS account,

554
00:25:56.153 --> 00:25:58.901
they actually limit you to 20 instances.

555
00:25:58.901 --> 00:26:01.556
And if you want more than 20 you gotta
do a support ticket with them and

556
00:26:01.556 --> 00:26:02.840
they'll remove that cap.

557
00:26:02.840 --> 00:26:05.520
They do that to stop somebody from
breaking into your account and

558
00:26:05.520 --> 00:26:08.733
launching a bunch of BitCoin miners,
which is what happens.

559
00:26:08.733 --> 00:26:09.625
[LAUGH]
>> Dear.

560
00:26:09.625 --> 00:26:11.630
>> So that gets expensive real fast.

561
00:26:11.630 --> 00:26:15.100
So I just want one, but
you can do more than one at the same time.

562
00:26:15.100 --> 00:26:17.740
After that I can pick
the network configuration.

563
00:26:17.740 --> 00:26:21.100
With the network, there's actually a few
different things, I'll save this for

564
00:26:21.100 --> 00:26:21.640
a little bit later.

565
00:26:21.640 --> 00:26:24.870
But you can create isolated networks,
what are called virtual private clouds or

566
00:26:24.870 --> 00:26:27.350
VPCs, and
isolate machines from the Internet.

567
00:26:27.350 --> 00:26:29.100
If you just leave it at the default,
though,

568
00:26:29.100 --> 00:26:33.990
the machine will get a public IP and
be accessible from the Internet,

569
00:26:33.990 --> 00:26:35.770
which is a lot of times
what we want on a server.

570
00:26:37.320 --> 00:26:39.950
Then as I scroll down I can
set up a shut down behavior.

571
00:26:39.950 --> 00:26:43.313
Be really careful with this,
because when you shut a machine down,

572
00:26:43.313 --> 00:26:45.919
there's two choices,
stop and terminate, okay?

573
00:26:45.919 --> 00:26:49.113
Stop, just means stop the VM from running,
shut it down.

574
00:26:49.113 --> 00:26:50.575
But we're gonna save the hard drives and

575
00:26:50.575 --> 00:26:52.610
you can power it back
on whenever you want.

576
00:26:52.610 --> 00:26:56.600
If you choose terminate, when you shut
the machine down, it deletes itself.

577
00:26:56.600 --> 00:27:00.290
Now that might sound really bad, why would
I want this machine to delete itself?

578
00:27:00.290 --> 00:27:03.972
But if I'm doing an autoscaling group or
I'm adding and removing machines all

579
00:27:03.972 --> 00:27:07.567
the time to cover a workload, I don't
need the old machines laying around.

580
00:27:07.567 --> 00:27:09.767
Cuz I can just rebuild them
easily when I need them so

581
00:27:09.767 --> 00:27:11.780
I want them to delete
when they're shut down.

582
00:27:11.780 --> 00:27:13.518
Normally you want stop though,
I'm gonna choose that.

583
00:27:13.518 --> 00:27:17.073
And you've got a little option here you
can check to protect against accidental

584
00:27:17.073 --> 00:27:18.270
termination.

585
00:27:18.270 --> 00:27:21.550
As long as termination protection is on,
you can't delete the machine,

586
00:27:21.550 --> 00:27:22.520
you can't terminate it.

587
00:27:22.520 --> 00:27:24.010
You'd have to go and
turn this option off first.

588
00:27:24.010 --> 00:27:26.580
So that's another way to protect
your machines from accidentally

589
00:27:26.580 --> 00:27:27.210
getting deleted.

590
00:27:28.760 --> 00:27:31.670
All right, on the next screen,
I can choose to add storage.

591
00:27:31.670 --> 00:27:35.060
And the default you'll see,
it's only got ten gigs of storage, and

592
00:27:35.060 --> 00:27:36.850
it's right here in the root disk.

593
00:27:36.850 --> 00:27:41.060
Now, Amazon encourages you not
to put data in the root disk.

594
00:27:41.060 --> 00:27:43.750
This is where the operating system is,
and if it swaps a file,

595
00:27:43.750 --> 00:27:45.080
that's where that's gonna go.

596
00:27:45.080 --> 00:27:49.700
You can put data there, but if you
need data storage, like a database or

597
00:27:49.700 --> 00:27:54.780
a website or whatever, they encourage you
to add a second disk and put it there.

598
00:27:54.780 --> 00:27:57.830
And the main reason is the way
this data is replicated.

599
00:27:57.830 --> 00:28:01.060
This is being built of
an Amazon Machine Image, an AMI.

600
00:28:01.060 --> 00:28:04.040
So this first disk comes out of the AMI.

601
00:28:04.040 --> 00:28:06.083
And if I ever re-deploy this,

602
00:28:06.083 --> 00:28:10.888
I'm not gonna have my custom data in
that unless I go and rebuild the AMI.

603
00:28:10.888 --> 00:28:13.512
Versus a second disk that
I can easily detach and

604
00:28:13.512 --> 00:28:17.820
reattach to any machine I wanted, so
it gives me a little flexibility.

605
00:28:17.820 --> 00:28:19.920
Always a good idea to
add that second disk.

606
00:28:19.920 --> 00:28:24.712
So I'm gonna add one, and then it shows me
right here on the screen that that second

607
00:28:24.712 --> 00:28:26.510
disk is gonna be /dev/sdb.

608
00:28:26.510 --> 00:28:27.790
I need to remember that.

609
00:28:27.790 --> 00:28:31.540
Because when I bring the machine up,
I'll need to format that disk and

610
00:28:31.540 --> 00:28:33.970
mount it to make it available and usable.

611
00:28:33.970 --> 00:28:37.790
But after that, I can pick the size,
and the size is up to me.

612
00:28:37.790 --> 00:28:41.510
You do have to pay for storage, right,
it's $0.10 per giga byte per month.

613
00:28:41.510 --> 00:28:44.350
So the more storage I consume
the more that's gonna cost me.

614
00:28:44.350 --> 00:28:47.700
It's doing, maybe I want a 64 gig disk,
so I can punch that in.

615
00:28:47.700 --> 00:28:50.060
Now the cost is variable.

616
00:28:50.060 --> 00:28:54.043
The cost is dependant on this
option right here, the volume type.

617
00:28:54.043 --> 00:28:57.160
And you'll see that it
defaults to SSD storage.

618
00:28:57.160 --> 00:28:59.510
That's nice and fast,
right, really fast storage.

619
00:28:59.510 --> 00:29:01.770
But it's not exclusive storage to me.

620
00:29:01.770 --> 00:29:04.090
I'm sharing IO with other systems.

621
00:29:04.090 --> 00:29:09.045
So if this is a really critical system,
like a database server that I need to

622
00:29:09.045 --> 00:29:13.845
have the best IO, I can pick Provisioned
iOPS, and I specify exactly how

623
00:29:13.845 --> 00:29:18.673
many input/output operations per
second I wanna reserve this system.

624
00:29:18.673 --> 00:29:23.243
I can guarantee disk performance,
it's twice as expensive, but

625
00:29:23.243 --> 00:29:24.718
it can do it, right?

626
00:29:24.718 --> 00:29:26.955
So if performance is a concern,
we can certainly do that.

627
00:29:26.955 --> 00:29:31.690
But for most of us, general purpossesity
is fine, that's what we need.

628
00:29:31.690 --> 00:29:35.182
And then, you typically don't wanna set
your data disk to delete on termination.

629
00:29:35.182 --> 00:29:38.878
And that way if you terminate an instance
you can reattach this data disk to some

630
00:29:38.878 --> 00:29:42.195
other system and access it, and
you've got the option to encrypt it.

631
00:29:42.195 --> 00:29:45.112
And remember normally when we
install Linux during the installer,

632
00:29:45.112 --> 00:29:48.180
we had that option to encrypt
our disk using Lux encryption.

633
00:29:48.180 --> 00:29:51.112
Well, Amazon can actually encrypt
the disk as part of the VM.

634
00:29:51.112 --> 00:29:54.310
So we have that option, if we want it.

635
00:29:54.310 --> 00:29:57.152
Once we've got our volume setup,
after that you got your tags.

636
00:29:57.152 --> 00:29:59.226
Tags are just ways that you
can filter your machines.

637
00:29:59.226 --> 00:30:02.310
If you've got 1,000 instances, it can be
confusing to find the ones you're looking

638
00:30:02.310 --> 00:30:04.040
for, so you can use tags to do it.

639
00:30:04.040 --> 00:30:06.170
I usually have one tag and
it's called a name tag.

640
00:30:06.170 --> 00:30:07.090
So it has name, right?

641
00:30:07.090 --> 00:30:08.560
I'm just gonna add a name tag.

642
00:30:08.560 --> 00:30:12.991
I'm gonna add it and
I'll call the server lab-rhel01, right?

643
00:30:12.991 --> 00:30:15.441
This will give me my
Red Hat Enterprise Linux server.

644
00:30:15.441 --> 00:30:18.530
You can change the name whenever you want,
it's not a permanent thing.

645
00:30:18.530 --> 00:30:20.431
Well, it's permanent if you don't go and
change it, right?

646
00:30:20.431 --> 00:30:23.770
[LAUGH] But you can change it if you want,
and that'll be available.

647
00:30:25.280 --> 00:30:26.910
On the next screen,
we've got security groups.

648
00:30:26.910 --> 00:30:29.533
And on the security group side,
here's where we can create basically,

649
00:30:29.533 --> 00:30:31.306
a software firewall that
protects our machine.

650
00:30:31.306 --> 00:30:33.118
And I wanna talk more about it later,
so right now,

651
00:30:33.118 --> 00:30:34.396
I'm gonna leave it at the default.

652
00:30:34.396 --> 00:30:37.770
The defaults says we want
to allow SSH on port 22.

653
00:30:37.770 --> 00:30:41.370
That's how I'm gonna get in and
manage this system and work with it, so

654
00:30:41.370 --> 00:30:43.220
I'll leave that at its own.

655
00:30:43.220 --> 00:30:45.220
And I'll hit review and launch.

656
00:30:45.220 --> 00:30:49.530
Now it gives me a chance to kinda
summarize the data that I saw.

657
00:30:49.530 --> 00:30:51.860
And I'm gonna go ahead and hit Launch.

658
00:30:51.860 --> 00:30:53.660
Now there's one thing that it
didn't set up for me yet, and

659
00:30:53.660 --> 00:30:57.210
that's authentication, right,
a username, and a password.

660
00:30:57.210 --> 00:31:00.630
Well, Amazon doesn't use usernames and
passwords on their Linux instances.

661
00:31:00.630 --> 00:31:04.100
Instead, they use certificate
based authentication.

662
00:31:04.100 --> 00:31:06.820
So when you set up your AWS account,

663
00:31:06.820 --> 00:31:09.880
you have the option to create
certificates to authenticate yourself.

664
00:31:09.880 --> 00:31:13.580
And you can use those to authenticate
yourself on the VM's as well, right?

665
00:31:13.580 --> 00:31:16.250
Or if you've never done it before,
you've got the option to come in here and

666
00:31:16.250 --> 00:31:16.780
create a new one.

667
00:31:16.780 --> 00:31:18.710
I can come in here and
create a new key pair.

668
00:31:18.710 --> 00:31:21.780
And it will generate a key, and I'll
have a chance to download it right here.

669
00:31:21.780 --> 00:31:25.790
And that will literally be
the only time I can download it.

670
00:31:25.790 --> 00:31:29.504
If I lose the file,
I can't log in to my machines.

671
00:31:29.504 --> 00:31:32.350
And the only thing I can do is delete
the machines and rebuild them, right?

672
00:31:32.350 --> 00:31:35.160
Amazon has no recovery mechanism for this.

673
00:31:35.160 --> 00:31:36.810
These are your private keys.

674
00:31:36.810 --> 00:31:39.480
If somebody gets the private keys,
they can break into the system, so

675
00:31:39.480 --> 00:31:40.780
there is no recovery.

676
00:31:40.780 --> 00:31:43.210
You download a key and
you've got it, right?

677
00:31:43.210 --> 00:31:45.120
So I've already generated my own key, and

678
00:31:45.120 --> 00:31:48.370
I've got the option here to choose
an existing key pair and I can pick it.

679
00:31:48.370 --> 00:31:51.356
And I have to acknowledge that
I have access to that key pair,

680
00:31:51.356 --> 00:31:53.030
cuz Amazon doesn't.

681
00:31:53.030 --> 00:31:56.788
And if I don't have the keys,
I just created a server I can't log into,

682
00:31:56.788 --> 00:31:57.427
all right.

683
00:31:57.427 --> 00:31:58.543
But you can create your own.

684
00:31:58.543 --> 00:32:00.655
If you do, you just create it here,
you give it a name, and

685
00:32:00.655 --> 00:32:02.136
then you can reuse it on other machines.

686
00:32:02.136 --> 00:32:04.947
Or you might create different keys for
every single machine you launch,

687
00:32:04.947 --> 00:32:06.478
if you're really security paranoid.

688
00:32:06.478 --> 00:32:07.950
You can certainly do that.

689
00:32:07.950 --> 00:32:12.098
And then after that, we launch
the instance and now it's firing up.

690
00:32:12.098 --> 00:32:13.950
Now, normally this would be
where the installer is running,

691
00:32:13.950 --> 00:32:16.470
copies files to the hard drive, reboots.

692
00:32:16.470 --> 00:32:18.240
That's not what is happening in Amazon.

693
00:32:18.240 --> 00:32:20.120
They've already got a machine built for
us.

694
00:32:20.120 --> 00:32:22.820
They deploy it onto hardware somewhere.

695
00:32:22.820 --> 00:32:24.900
We don't necessarily know
where that hardware is.

696
00:32:24.900 --> 00:32:27.490
We know the data center, but
not where in that data center it is.

697
00:32:27.490 --> 00:32:31.100
It deploys that server,
it brings it online, and

698
00:32:31.100 --> 00:32:32.110
then we'll be able to access it.

699
00:32:32.110 --> 00:32:35.930
If I scroll down, there's a button that's
kinda hidden, it says View Instances.

700
00:32:35.930 --> 00:32:37.315
Actually, it's hidden by my big head.

701
00:32:37.315 --> 00:32:38.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

702
00:32:38.020 --> 00:32:41.390
down here at the bottom is a blue button
that says View Instances and if I click

703
00:32:41.390 --> 00:32:47.140
that, it'll take me back to the dashboard
and this time I see my instances, okay?

704
00:32:47.140 --> 00:32:49.828
Now, normally the instance state,
this one went really fast, but

705
00:32:49.828 --> 00:32:52.400
normally the instance state
will say initializing.

706
00:32:52.400 --> 00:32:55.520
It takes a little while to setup, and
so you'll see a yellow circle and

707
00:32:55.520 --> 00:32:56.950
it will say initializing.

708
00:32:56.950 --> 00:33:01.750
And when the machine is done, it'll change
to a green light and it will say running.

709
00:33:01.750 --> 00:33:03.400
And actually, right here,
the status check.

710
00:33:03.400 --> 00:33:05.900
The status check is still
showing initializing.

711
00:33:05.900 --> 00:33:09.680
So it's initializing, I'm waiting for
this machine to be fully ready.

712
00:33:09.680 --> 00:33:12.650
It's running, but
the OS is doing the final initialization.

713
00:33:12.650 --> 00:33:13.726
It's gotta add that other disk and

714
00:33:13.726 --> 00:33:16.150
the other things that we told
it to do during the installer.

715
00:33:16.150 --> 00:33:19.150
As soon as that initializing
changes to a healthy check,

716
00:33:19.150 --> 00:33:20.920
it'll have a little green light and
it'll say 2/2.

717
00:33:20.920 --> 00:33:23.670
It'll let me know that it passed
two checks, the hardware and

718
00:33:23.670 --> 00:33:24.810
the software checks.

719
00:33:24.810 --> 00:33:28.850
And once that's good, we'll be ready
to login, access the machine, and

720
00:33:28.850 --> 00:33:30.110
start to work with it.

721
00:33:30.110 --> 00:33:32.070
>> Yeah, I was gonna say,
now that the instance is up and

722
00:33:32.070 --> 00:33:33.720
running, how do we log into it?

723
00:33:33.720 --> 00:33:37.061
All right, well logging into it,
we've gotta use our certificates, and

724
00:33:37.061 --> 00:33:38.770
that's a bit of an involved process.

725
00:33:38.770 --> 00:33:41.100
Now I wanna walk you guys through it,
but looking at the time at the clock,

726
00:33:41.100 --> 00:33:42.560
I don't think I have enough time to do it.

727
00:33:42.560 --> 00:33:47.060
So let's do this, let's split into
a two-parter on this one, and

728
00:33:47.060 --> 00:33:50.270
in the second part, I'll show you guys
how to get logged into that instance.

729
00:33:50.270 --> 00:33:53.027
We still need to get logged in,
do our initial updates and

730
00:33:53.027 --> 00:33:56.320
then start to work with this
Linux server that we built up.

731
00:33:56.320 --> 00:33:57.988
So, that's what we'll tackle in part two.

732
00:33:57.988 --> 00:34:02.260
>> Awesome information, Don and who

733
00:34:02.260 --> 00:34:04.075
It's more than Amazon Prime,

734
00:34:04.075 --> 00:34:06.450
>> [LAUGH]
>> Creating an EC2 instance.

735
00:34:06.450 --> 00:34:07.660
Now, this is part one.

736
00:34:07.660 --> 00:34:08.500
There will be part two.

737
00:34:08.500 --> 00:34:09.630
Please make sure you watch that.

738
00:34:09.630 --> 00:34:11.830
Don, anything else you
wanna say before we go?

739
00:34:11.830 --> 00:34:13.390
>> This is better than Amazon Prime.

00:34:13.390 --> 00:34:15.230
I didn't have to wait two days for
it to be shipped to me,

741
00:34:15.230 --> 00:34:16.580
that server's already up.

742
00:34:16.580 --> 00:34:17.440
>> Fantastic.

743
00:34:17.440 --> 00:34:19.560
>> Do be aware that there
is a cost concern, right?

744
00:34:19.560 --> 00:34:21.630
That if you forget about a machine and

00:34:21.630 --> 00:34:22.740
you're still paying for it, right?

00:34:22.740 --> 00:34:24.060
So we do always have to be aware of that.

747
00:34:24.060 --> 00:34:26.860
This is not free, but
it is really a great solution.

748
00:34:26.860 --> 00:34:28.850
Definitely the way of the future and

749
00:34:28.850 --> 00:34:30.140
And stay tuned for part two though,

750
00:34:30.140 --> 00:34:33.510
cuz we've really only kinda

00:34:33.510 --> 00:34:38.320

00:34:40.800 --> 00:34:41.575

00:34:41.575 --> 00:34:43.970

00:34:43.970 --> 00:34:46.510

account to manage the server.

237
00:11:39.170 --> 00:11:41.650
And so if I remove it,
it can break some of that.

238
00:11:41.650 --> 00:11:43.950
But if I don't care about that,
if I'm gonna set up my own monitoring.

239
00:11:43.950 --> 00:11:46.670
If I want this to be my own machine,
then I've got full access.

240
00:11:46.670 --> 00:11:49.290
You can do whatever you want
inside of that guest OS.

241
00:11:49.290 --> 00:11:52.540
As far as creating users, customizing it,

242
00:11:52.540 --> 00:11:55.360
and doing all of that just like
you would a normal system.

243
00:11:55.360 --> 00:11:57.170
>> Don,
I think you've touched on this already.

244
00:11:57.170 --> 00:11:59.530
Does Amazon automatically
update our servers?

245
00:11:59.530 --> 00:12:01.160
And if so, how often do they do that?

246
00:12:02.430 --> 00:12:05.148
>> So in the last episode,
I talked a little bit about updates.

247
00:12:05.148 --> 00:12:06.279
>> Yeah, you touched on that.

248
00:12:06.279 --> 00:12:10.419
>> I said when
Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.4 came out,

249
00:12:10.419 --> 00:12:14.928
Amazon, that same day,
already had an AMI up for 7.4.

250
00:12:14.928 --> 00:12:19.120
So when I roll out a new instance,
it's got the latest and greatest, right?

251
00:12:19.120 --> 00:12:22.917
But let's say that I've
got this instance up, and

252
00:12:22.917 --> 00:12:27.257
if I run hostNameCTL,
I can see that I'm running 7.4.

253
00:12:27.257 --> 00:12:30.890
And let's say that 7.5 came out, okay?

254
00:12:30.890 --> 00:12:35.480
Amazon does not upgrade
your running instances.

255
00:12:35.480 --> 00:12:40.140
They'll put out a new AMI for 7.5,
and if I roll out new instances,

256
00:12:40.140 --> 00:12:43.440
I can use the 7.5 AMI and
now they're running 7.5.

257
00:12:43.440 --> 00:12:44.910
But you're running instances,

258
00:12:44.910 --> 00:12:48.520
the moment you start them,
it becomes your problem, right?

259
00:12:48.520 --> 00:12:53.310
Amazon gives you the infrastructure,
they don't support the OS, so

260
00:12:53.310 --> 00:12:57.100
all maintenance to the OS,
all updates to the OS, that's up to you.

261
00:12:57.100 --> 00:13:02.000
So once you deploy it,
that AMI may not be that recent.

262
00:13:02.000 --> 00:13:05.600
It may be months old or longer, right?

263
00:13:05.600 --> 00:13:07.910
And if that's the case,
the moment you fire this thing up,

264
00:13:07.910 --> 00:13:09.370
the first thing you need to do is update.

265
00:13:09.370 --> 00:13:12.650
And then periodically you need
to continue doing updates.

266
00:13:12.650 --> 00:13:14.990
But when I spun this up,
if I poke around a little more,

267
00:13:14.990 --> 00:13:18.780
there's actually a few neat little
deployment images you can find.

268
00:13:19.950 --> 00:13:24.170
Some of these, if you look at
the main ones here in Quick Access,

269
00:13:24.170 --> 00:13:26.390
these things aren't updated
all that frequently.

270
00:13:26.390 --> 00:13:28.560
It's just whenever a major
version comes out.

271
00:13:28.560 --> 00:13:31.230
But minor updates come out all the time.

272
00:13:31.230 --> 00:13:33.380
And I know there's a Red Hat one.

273
00:13:33.380 --> 00:13:36.670
Let me look and see if I can find it.

274
00:13:36.670 --> 00:13:40.490
There's a Red Hat one that's
kinda special that is, actually,

275
00:13:40.490 --> 00:13:42.100
it might be under community AMIs.

276
00:13:42.100 --> 00:13:45.210
Let's see if we can find it here on AGL.

277
00:13:45.210 --> 00:13:46.780
And I'm looking for a particular one.

278
00:13:46.780 --> 00:13:47.360
Right here.

279
00:13:47.360 --> 00:13:48.640
This first one.

280
00:13:48.640 --> 00:13:50.955
If you look at the name of this one,
all right?

281
00:13:50.955 --> 00:13:53.730
RHEL-7.4_HVM is a hardware
virtual machine.

282
00:13:53.730 --> 00:13:55.900
So this is kinda like what I'm running.

283
00:13:55.900 --> 00:14:00.474
But over here it says 2-Hourly2-GP2.

284
00:14:00.474 --> 00:14:02.308
Okay, what does that mean?

285
00:14:02.308 --> 00:14:04.810
Hourly2, okay?

286
00:14:04.810 --> 00:14:08.630
This one is being updated hourly.

287
00:14:08.630 --> 00:14:11.280
They're constantly pushing
out updates to this thing.

288
00:14:11.280 --> 00:14:13.600
So, I know that I get the latest one.

289
00:14:13.600 --> 00:14:16.370
Now, I might not want that because
I need to test my updates,

290
00:14:16.370 --> 00:14:20.210
I need to make sure that I'm running
something that's stable in my environment.

291
00:14:20.210 --> 00:14:22.400
So really, the update's left up to me.

292
00:14:22.400 --> 00:14:23.550
As soon as I deploy it,

293
00:14:23.550 --> 00:14:27.730
even if I use an hourly image, as soon as
that's deployed that hourly stuff is gone.

294
00:14:27.730 --> 00:14:30.610
Now, it's up to me to do the updates.

295
00:14:31.750 --> 00:14:37.237
Fortunately, it is controlled just like
any other system, that once I'm in here

296
00:14:37.237 --> 00:14:42.340
I can do a sudo yum update, and it's
gonna reach out and it's gonna update.

297
00:14:42.340 --> 00:14:44.800
And look who it's reaching out to?

298
00:14:44.800 --> 00:14:46.950
It's reaching out to Red Hat servers.

299
00:14:46.950 --> 00:14:51.930
It's reaching out to their distros, the
repos because it's their operating system.

300
00:14:51.930 --> 00:14:53.750
And so there is found some updates.

301
00:14:53.750 --> 00:14:55.280
There's a kernel update, that's a big one.

302
00:14:56.880 --> 00:14:58.140
So we can go and deploy that.

303
00:14:58.140 --> 00:14:59.740
And it's going to put them in Ubuntu.

304
00:14:59.740 --> 00:15:05.840
I can do the same thing, right,
Ubuntu it's sudo apt update.

305
00:15:05.840 --> 00:15:06.870
I can run that.

306
00:15:06.870 --> 00:15:09.550
And oops, I got to spell sudo, right?

307
00:15:09.550 --> 00:15:13.470
So, sudo apt update, it checks for
the updates, and as soon as it

308
00:15:13.470 --> 00:15:16.060
finds them that it got used to a second
command to actually apply them.

309
00:15:16.060 --> 00:15:18.230
We'll do a sudo apt upgrade.

310
00:15:18.230 --> 00:15:19.320
There we go.

311
00:15:19.320 --> 00:15:22.700
So there was update, it found the new
packages, I'll do an upgrade, and

312
00:15:22.700 --> 00:15:24.960
here it is,
actually upgrading 30 packages.

313
00:15:24.960 --> 00:15:26.320
And so it's applying them, right.

314
00:15:26.320 --> 00:15:26.940
>> Fantastic.

315
00:15:26.940 --> 00:15:29.350
>> It's up to me to do it though,
and I'll tell you,

316
00:15:29.350 --> 00:15:33.660
when they're minor updates like this,
you can just use your typical utility.

317
00:15:33.660 --> 00:15:36.640
You can set up Cron Jobs to do it, or
if you're actually testing your updates,

318
00:15:36.640 --> 00:15:37.780
then you'll do it this way.

319
00:15:37.780 --> 00:15:41.760
But, when they're major upgrades, I never
do a major upgrade this way, right?

320
00:15:41.760 --> 00:15:44.490
Even Red Hat where the major
upgrade's usually pretty easy,

321
00:15:45.610 --> 00:15:46.270
I don't do it this way.

322
00:15:46.270 --> 00:15:48.480
Instead it's easier to just
spin up a new instance.

323
00:15:48.480 --> 00:15:49.604
And say, all right, I'm running 7.4 now.

324
00:15:49.604 --> 00:15:53.120
7.5 came out.
So let me just spin up a 7.5 instance.

325
00:15:53.120 --> 00:15:56.101
And then I can transfer my
data over to it easy enough,

326
00:15:56.101 --> 00:16:00.273
it just depends on how you want to do
that, but updates are really up to you,

327
00:16:00.273 --> 00:16:02.925
you're responsible for them, not Amazon.

328
00:16:02.925 --> 00:16:04.497
>> Okay, what about backups zone?

329
00:16:04.497 --> 00:16:05.468
Do we backup our own servers?

330
00:16:05.468 --> 00:16:09.166
>> Okay, backups,
Amazon sort of does backups for us,

331
00:16:09.166 --> 00:16:14.673
in that they guarantee if the hard drives
that are supporting your system fail,

332
00:16:14.673 --> 00:16:19.113
that they have another copy of your
system that will take over and

333
00:16:19.113 --> 00:16:22.930
you'll survive that hard drive failure,
okay?

334
00:16:22.930 --> 00:16:26.820
So from that perspective,
we don't need backups, right?

335
00:16:26.820 --> 00:16:31.260
But Amazon is guaranteeing
the current state of your machine.

336
00:16:32.320 --> 00:16:35.050
>> What if I deleted a file four days ago?

337
00:16:35.050 --> 00:16:36.580
Well, it's gone.

338
00:16:36.580 --> 00:16:37.790
It's just deleted.

339
00:16:37.790 --> 00:16:41.010
Amazon's giving me a current backup,
which means how my server looks right now,

340
00:16:41.010 --> 00:16:46.150
with that file deleted, so
it's not a true substitute for backups.

341
00:16:46.150 --> 00:16:48.630
Well they do guarantee the integrity
of your server right now,

342
00:16:48.630 --> 00:16:51.870
if you think you're gonna
get any historical data

343
00:16:51.870 --> 00:16:55.010
you're going to need to set up a back
up system of some sort, right.

344
00:16:55.010 --> 00:16:57.820
And it's really no different
than backing up a local server.

345
00:16:57.820 --> 00:17:00.940
Except, we do actually
have one neat feature.

346
00:17:00.940 --> 00:17:04.010
When I created this server
I created the data disk and

347
00:17:04.010 --> 00:17:06.210
the data disk is where
I would put my data.

348
00:17:06.210 --> 00:17:11.370
Actually, I never set it up but
either it was a /dev/SDB,

349
00:17:11.370 --> 00:17:17.050
and so if I were to get in here in
fdisk/dev/SDB, I could go in and.

350
00:17:17.050 --> 00:17:19.540
I thought I did maybe
it's not SDB [LAUGH].

351
00:17:19.540 --> 00:17:24.170
So I need to take a look at my /step and
figure out what the heck it's called.

352
00:17:24.170 --> 00:17:27.130
I could format the disk, mount it,
start putting my data there.

353
00:17:27.130 --> 00:17:32.050
When you create that it's being put on
whats called elastic block storage or EBS.

354
00:17:32.050 --> 00:17:36.730
An EBS storage is replicated across a
couple of storage units inside of Amazon.

355
00:17:36.730 --> 00:17:38.310
In fact, there's three copies.

356
00:17:38.310 --> 00:17:42.540
There's the live copy on the server
you're using, there's a second copy in

357
00:17:42.540 --> 00:17:47.670
the same data center and then there's a
third copy stored in another data center.

358
00:17:47.670 --> 00:17:49.990
That's how amazon guarantees
that data will be protected, but

359
00:17:49.990 --> 00:17:51.480
it's all the current data.

360
00:17:51.480 --> 00:17:55.400
They don't maintain historical data So
if I wanna maintain historical data, and

361
00:17:55.400 --> 00:18:01.650
I've got this volume setup, what I can do
is I can go in, I can find my instance.

362
00:18:01.650 --> 00:18:05.920
Let me cancel out of this, and
go back to my instance list.

363
00:18:05.920 --> 00:18:08.360
I can take, like a Red Hat server, right,

364
00:18:08.360 --> 00:18:11.880
and it's going to have
volumes attached to it.

365
00:18:11.880 --> 00:18:15.130
And I can take a snapshot
of those volumes.

366
00:18:15.130 --> 00:18:19.210
And I can take a snapshot once a day or
once a hour, once a week and

367
00:18:19.210 --> 00:18:22.950
it'll take an image of that
volume like it is right now.

368
00:18:22.950 --> 00:18:26.520
It's like an instantaneous back up and
now I've got it available.

369
00:18:26.520 --> 00:18:29.810
So I could pick an instance like this and
I could go to Actions.

370
00:18:29.810 --> 00:18:33.290
And under Actions,
you'll see where we've got,

371
00:18:33.290 --> 00:18:37.440
let's see it is buried in here somewhere,
we will find it.

372
00:18:37.440 --> 00:18:40.203
Actually is it not in here,
am I lying to you?

373
00:18:40.203 --> 00:18:43.880
We've got [LAUGH] I could have
swore it was right in here.

374
00:18:43.880 --> 00:18:46.580
I don't normally come this way, cuz I
normally back up the individual instances.

375
00:18:46.580 --> 00:18:51.080
But I thought you could back up the whole
Instance, but I don't see that option.

376
00:18:51.080 --> 00:18:52.660
All right well,
apparently you can't do it this way.

377
00:18:52.660 --> 00:18:55.400
So, normally what I do is I
back up the individual volumes,

378
00:18:55.400 --> 00:18:58.170
because I don't care about
the instance itself, right?

379
00:18:58.170 --> 00:19:00.620
The AMI,
I got that from Amazon anyway, right?

380
00:19:00.620 --> 00:19:01.940
I can deploy that in a heartbeat.

381
00:19:01.940 --> 00:19:03.230
I don't need a backup of the AMI.

382
00:19:03.230 --> 00:19:05.300
I need a backup of my data.

383
00:19:05.300 --> 00:19:07.020
So I usually back up
the individual volume,

384
00:19:07.020 --> 00:19:10.225
but there used to be an option,
I know it used to be here.

385
00:19:10.225 --> 00:19:13.300
That you could choose an instance,
go to action, and you could come in and

386
00:19:13.300 --> 00:19:17.160
choose to take a snapshot of it,
but apparently they moved that off.

387
00:19:17.160 --> 00:19:20.270
But to do it with the individual volume
way, the way that I like anyway,

388
00:19:20.270 --> 00:19:24.590
on the left side if you scroll down,
you'll find Volumes.

389
00:19:24.590 --> 00:19:27.940
And right here you can see all
the volumes attached to your system.

390
00:19:27.940 --> 00:19:31.560
And I can see the ten gig volume
attached to my red hat server,

391
00:19:31.560 --> 00:19:33.960
which is the one
the operating system is on.

392
00:19:33.960 --> 00:19:38.580
And then I can see the 64 gig volume
that I added as my data disk.

393
00:19:38.580 --> 00:19:40.670
So there's my data disk and

394
00:19:40.670 --> 00:19:45.520
I can go to Actions, and
from here I can create a snapshot.

395
00:19:45.520 --> 00:19:48.320
And a snapshot is an instantaneous backup.

396
00:19:48.320 --> 00:19:48.960
I can give it a name.

397
00:19:48.960 --> 00:19:50.535
I can call it back up dash.

398
00:19:50.535 --> 00:19:51.367
What is today?

399
00:19:51.367 --> 00:19:56.890
It's 08-24-2017 or however it is
that I wanted to name this thing.

400
00:19:56.890 --> 00:19:59.800
I can give it a description and
I can create it.

401
00:19:59.800 --> 00:20:03.164
And it takes a snapshot, so
the snapshot creation is started, and so

402
00:20:03.164 --> 00:20:05.210
it's snapshotting that disk.

403
00:20:05.210 --> 00:20:09.460
Everything that is on it, at its current
state, it's placed in a snapshot.

404
00:20:09.460 --> 00:20:12.190
And then the volume continues to go on and
change like normal.

405
00:20:12.190 --> 00:20:15.530
And at any time, I can go into
Snapshots here on the left side,

406
00:20:15.530 --> 00:20:17.350
and I'll see that snapshot.

407
00:20:17.350 --> 00:20:19.000
And I can restore it, right?

408
00:20:19.000 --> 00:20:20.550
All I have to do is
detach the current drive,

409
00:20:20.550 --> 00:20:22.790
and attach this snapshot,
and I'm in business.

410
00:20:22.790 --> 00:20:25.610
Or I can attach this snapshot
to other servers somewhere else.

411
00:20:25.610 --> 00:20:30.480
And I can keep taking snapshots and
this becomes my backup system, all right?

412
00:20:30.480 --> 00:20:34.305
No tape rotation, no worrying about
replication, I just take these snapshots,

413
00:20:34.305 --> 00:20:37.140
and they get dumped in here,
and I pay for storage.

414
00:20:37.140 --> 00:20:38.055
Right?
Every snapshot is

415
00:20:38.055 --> 00:20:39.335
gonna cost me a little bit of money,

416
00:20:39.335 --> 00:20:43.755
but we're talking about ten cents per gig
per month, less, depending on your volume.

417
00:20:43.755 --> 00:20:47.535
So it's not a lot of money to keep these
backups and now I've got that solution.

418
00:20:47.535 --> 00:20:50.975
But I just need to create a policy,
a procedure to follow, that says,

419
00:20:50.975 --> 00:20:55.115
here's how frequently I backup this data,
and then I've got it right here.

420
00:20:55.115 --> 00:20:56.575
>> Awesome, awesome.

421
00:20:56.575 --> 00:20:58.245
I really have enjoyed this.

422
00:20:58.245 --> 00:21:00.635
I never knew Amazon had so
much to offer and, John,

00:21:00.635 --> 00:21:01.905

424
00:21:01.905 --> 00:21:02.910

425
00:21:02.910 --> 00:21:05.360
Creating an EC2 instance part two.

426
00:21:05.360 --> 00:21:07.190
Don, anything else you'd like to add?

427
00:21:07.190 --> 00:21:09.590
>> Well, once you've spun up that
Linux instance inside of EC2,

00:21:09.590 --> 00:21:12.310

00:21:12.310 --> 00:21:15.820
There are some more advanced things

00:21:15.820 --> 00:21:18.320

or the firewalls.

431
00:21:18.320 --> 00:21:20.451
So we'll do a little
bit of security stuff.

432
00:21:20.451 --> 00:21:22.880
But if you're ever intimidated by this,
don't be.

433
00:21:22.880 --> 00:21:25.900
You can drop and Instance right in
there and have it up and running and

434
00:21:25.900 --> 00:21:27.370
you'll be working just
like any other server.

435
00:21:27.370 --> 00:21:31.220
It really runs great on top of Amazon's
infrastructure which is top notch.

436
00:21:31.220 --> 00:21:33.910
So, definitely something
worth checking out.

437
00:21:33.910 --> 00:21:35.070
>> I do love my job.

00:21:41.650 --> 00:21:43.350

00:21:43.350 --> 00:21:44.070

00:21:44.070 --> 00:21:45.380
Don does a marvelous job.

00:21:45.380 --> 00:21:47.250

00:21:47.250 --> 00:21:50.860
