00:15:09.450 --> 00:15:12.750
And this is one of those things where you
want to have it done before you need it,

273
00:15:12.750 --> 00:15:15.970
not after you need it, so setting up
a back up is kind of an important part.

274
00:15:15.970 --> 00:15:17.710
It's not very hard to do.

275
00:15:17.710 --> 00:15:21.030
On the left side here, we're gonna
go down to our virtual machines.

276
00:15:21.030 --> 00:15:22.600
And when we pull up our virtual machines,

277
00:15:22.600 --> 00:15:24.240
we can find them when
we want them back up.

278
00:15:24.240 --> 00:15:28.480
I'm gonna do lab web server one,
mostly cuz it's the only one I have.

279
00:15:28.480 --> 00:15:31.830
And then if I look down at
the options here on the left side,

280
00:15:31.830 --> 00:15:34.980
about half way down, I've got backup.

281
00:15:34.980 --> 00:15:37.100
And here's where we can
set up our back up.

282
00:15:37.100 --> 00:15:40.680
And it's really designed to
work a few different ways.

283
00:15:40.680 --> 00:15:43.420
You can do one time manual back ups or

284
00:15:43.420 --> 00:15:46.890
you can do scheduled back
ups that run on their own.

285
00:15:46.890 --> 00:15:51.000
Be aware that each back up is gonna
get stored into a storage group and

286
00:15:51.000 --> 00:15:53.470
you have to pay for the storage you use.

287
00:15:53.470 --> 00:15:58.200
It's something like 10 cents per gigabyte
per month, 11 cents, something like that.

288
00:15:58.200 --> 00:16:00.027
It's not a ton of money, but
you do it to pay for it.

289
00:16:00.027 --> 00:16:03.312
So you don't wanna keep a ton of
backups lying around if you don't

290
00:16:03.312 --> 00:16:04.395
actually need them.

291
00:16:04.395 --> 00:16:06.257
>> Right.
>> Cuz they will cost you.

292
00:16:06.257 --> 00:16:09.303
So it's offering to create a vault for
me, and

293
00:16:09.303 --> 00:16:12.045
a vault is where we're gonna store this.

294
00:16:12.045 --> 00:16:16.600
And vault storage is a little cheaper than
normal storage, so that's a good thing.

295
00:16:16.600 --> 00:16:19.240
But if I don't have a vault,
I need to create a new one.

296
00:16:19.240 --> 00:16:22.347
And so
I might call this my lab-backup-vault or

297
00:16:22.347 --> 00:16:24.633
whatever it is that I wanna name it.

298
00:16:24.633 --> 00:16:28.423
If I already had a vault I could pick
the one that already existed, right?

299
00:16:28.423 --> 00:16:31.175
And then I can define a policy.

300
00:16:31.175 --> 00:16:34.802
The default policy that they wanna
create for me is called a daily policy.

301
00:16:34.802 --> 00:16:39.014
And so if you look, it's gonna
create a daily policy where every

302
00:16:39.014 --> 00:16:42.215
day at 4:00 AM UTC,
it's gonna do a backup.

303
00:16:42.215 --> 00:16:45.140
All right, now that might not work for me.

304
00:16:45.140 --> 00:16:47.320
First off,
I might not wanna backup everyday,

305
00:16:47.320 --> 00:16:48.840
I might wanna backup less frequently.

306
00:16:48.840 --> 00:16:50.963
So I could come in and
I could change that,

307
00:16:50.963 --> 00:16:53.341
you can do weekly backups if you want,
right?

308
00:16:53.341 --> 00:16:57.117
But if I want to do something more
frequently than a daily backup they're not

309
00:16:57.117 --> 00:17:00.372
really giving me that option,
I'd have to go a different route.

310
00:17:00.372 --> 00:17:02.085
And usually daily backups are enough for

311
00:17:02.085 --> 00:17:05.012
most of us cuz you have other things
that you can do, like snapshots.

312
00:17:05.012 --> 00:17:08.398
You could do those every hour if you
wanted, or every 15 minutes, and

313
00:17:08.398 --> 00:17:11.623
then combine that with backups like
this to get a perfect solution.

314
00:17:11.623 --> 00:17:14.268
Then I pick the time, 4:00 AM UTC.

315
00:17:14.268 --> 00:17:18.257
That might sound good but
in our time zone that's actually 11PM.

316
00:17:18.257 --> 00:17:22.150
At 11PM there's a pretty decent amount
of people that might be in the system.

317
00:17:22.150 --> 00:17:24.709
So I might wanna change this to
something that's a little bit later,

318
00:17:24.709 --> 00:17:26.510
I'm gonna go with 7:00 AM UTC.

319
00:17:26.510 --> 00:17:28.422
Or if you're not all about
converting time zones,

320
00:17:28.422 --> 00:17:30.345
you could just switch this
to your local time zone.

321
00:17:30.345 --> 00:17:36.365
We are GMT -05:00, and so
in GMT -05:00, there we go.

322
00:17:36.365 --> 00:17:40.776
I can set it and say, you know what,
I want it to be at 2:00 AM or

323
00:17:40.776 --> 00:17:42.882
3:00 AM our time, right?

324
00:17:42.882 --> 00:17:46.370
And that way we know every day
it's gonna back up at that time.

325
00:17:46.370 --> 00:17:49.836
You wanna pick a non-peak time cuz you do
take a bit of a disk I/O hit when this

326
00:17:49.836 --> 00:17:51.689
happens and it can affect performance.

327
00:17:52.850 --> 00:17:55.550
After that I can specify
a retention range.

328
00:17:55.550 --> 00:17:58.602
How long do I wanna retain the backup for?

329
00:17:58.602 --> 00:18:01.467
And it's defaulting to 180 days.

330
00:18:01.467 --> 00:18:06.056
That means if I'm doing a daily
backup it's gonna maintain

331
00:18:06.056 --> 00:18:09.098
180 days worth of backups, right?

332
00:18:09.098 --> 00:18:11.259
That's a lot of backups.

333
00:18:11.259 --> 00:18:11.900
>> It is.

334
00:18:11.900 --> 00:18:15.840
>> I can tell it to make
weekly backup points instead.

335
00:18:15.840 --> 00:18:20.022
And that way it'll maintain
the last seven daily backups but

336
00:18:20.022 --> 00:18:25.540
then beyond that it'll start rolling
up weekly backups and saving those.

337
00:18:25.540 --> 00:18:26.900
And so I could come in and
say you know what,

338
00:18:26.900 --> 00:18:31.750
I just wanna do a 7-day daily backup.

339
00:18:31.750 --> 00:18:35.340
But then I wanna do a weekly backup,
I'll do every Sunday,

340
00:18:35.340 --> 00:18:37.740
and maybe I wanna keep 8 weeks, right?

341
00:18:37.740 --> 00:18:39.730
Two months worth of backups.

342
00:18:39.730 --> 00:18:42.660
You can kind of specify how you want
to minimize the amount of impact

343
00:18:42.660 --> 00:18:43.640
that you're gonna take.

344
00:18:43.640 --> 00:18:45.830
And we can even do the same thing for
monthly.

345
00:18:45.830 --> 00:18:49.790
And so I might come in and
say I'm gonna do a Week Based monthly,

346
00:18:49.790 --> 00:18:53.280
and I'll just take the first
Sunday of every month.

347
00:18:53.280 --> 00:18:54.958
And maybe I wanna go out 12 months.

348
00:18:54.958 --> 00:18:59.440
So now I'll have the last
seven days of backups, I'll

349
00:18:59.440 --> 00:19:04.520
have the last eight weeks of backups, and
I'll have the last 12 months of backups.

350
00:19:04.520 --> 00:19:09.110
So if I need to go all the way back to
a year ago I can with my monthlies,

351
00:19:09.110 --> 00:19:12.320
if I need to go five weeks ago,
I can with my weeklies.

352
00:19:12.320 --> 00:19:15.710
And if I need to go five days ago,
I can with my dailies.

353
00:19:15.710 --> 00:19:19.920
I'm building a backup policy
that matches my needs, right?

354
00:19:19.920 --> 00:19:22.680
And we can go yearly but
eventually it gets a little crazy.

355
00:19:22.680 --> 00:19:24.880
So we could start to setup all that.

356
00:19:24.880 --> 00:19:27.770
But it's all about minimizing the amount
of storage that we're consuming.

357
00:19:27.770 --> 00:19:30.980
I don't wanna eat up a ton of storage
maintaining a bunch of backups

358
00:19:30.980 --> 00:19:32.600
I don't necessarily need.

359
00:19:32.600 --> 00:19:36.620
So I get that set the way that I want and
then we can say OK to that.

360
00:19:36.620 --> 00:19:39.620
And now it's gonna build that policy.

361
00:19:39.620 --> 00:19:41.588
Once the policy's built
we hit Enable Backup and

362
00:19:41.588 --> 00:19:43.870
that's what actually gonna turn it on,
okay?

363
00:19:43.870 --> 00:19:47.683
So that's turning it on, it's initializing
that deployment and I'll have to wait,

364
00:19:47.683 --> 00:19:50.285

365
00:19:50.285 --> 00:19:50.959
>> [LAUGH]
>> But at 3AM,

366
00:19:50.959 --> 00:19:53.466
I should've picked something that
was like two minutes from now.

367
00:19:53.466 --> 00:19:55.512
>> We'll be back at 3 AM
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] so

368
00:19:55.512 --> 00:19:58.740
at 3AM we'll be all bleary-eyed
trying to do the show.

369
00:19:58.740 --> 00:20:01.610
But it's gonna run that backup and
it's gonna store it.

370
00:20:01.610 --> 00:20:03.392
And we'll be able to
monitor that as we need it,

371
00:20:03.392 --> 00:20:04.920
see that those backups are occurring.

372
00:20:04.920 --> 00:20:07.810
They'll show up in your little
bell menu and other areas.

373
00:20:07.810 --> 00:20:10.960
But once they're done,
now I can restore from them.

374
00:20:10.960 --> 00:20:12.510
If I have a problem
with a virtual machine,

375
00:20:12.510 --> 00:20:16.710
I can go in and I can restore that
backup and put it back the way it was.

376
00:20:16.710 --> 00:20:19.670
So if I come in first thing in the morning
and the website's been defaced,

377
00:20:19.670 --> 00:20:21.120
I need to find out why, right?

378
00:20:21.120 --> 00:20:23.820
So I might take a snapshot
of it as it was defaced.

379
00:20:23.820 --> 00:20:27.430
But then I can quickly restore
the backup and it's back online.

380
00:20:27.430 --> 00:20:30.470
And now we can go in and troubleshoot and
not affect our customers.

381
00:20:30.470 --> 00:20:32.805
Or if I wanna restore to another region,
I can do that.

382
00:20:32.805 --> 00:20:35.820
But backups are actually being
stored in multiple regions,

383
00:20:35.820 --> 00:20:39.320
Microsoft is doing that to ensure that
you always have access to your backups.

384
00:20:39.320 --> 00:20:43.400
And they're being put into a storage
vault that is a special storage tier, so

385
00:20:43.400 --> 00:20:45.940
it's not as expensive as normal storage.

386
00:20:45.940 --> 00:20:49.100
So all of that's going on in the
background and it's taking care of us for

387
00:20:49.100 --> 00:20:52.645
now, we set it and forget it, right,
it's like the rotisserie chicken.

388
00:20:52.645 --> 00:20:55.960
>> [LAUGH]
>> We set that thing and now it just runs,

389
00:20:55.960 --> 00:20:57.960
and when we need it we know
it'll be there for us.

390
00:20:57.960 --> 00:21:01.490
All part of my initial setup of
a virtual machine inside of Azure.

391
00:21:01.490 --> 00:21:05.600
>> And that chicken is cooking away,
configuring Azure VM.

392
00:21:05.600 --> 00:21:07.610
Don, any last words before we move on?

393
00:21:07.610 --> 00:21:11.450
The only other thing that I wanna mention
is don't trust the backups blindly.

394
00:21:11.450 --> 00:21:13.840
Make sure you run some tests,
do a test restore,

395
00:21:13.840 --> 00:21:18.000
try to restore it to another region and
see, make sure that all works for you.

396
00:21:18.000 --> 00:21:20.960
You'll also have other things that'll
be part of your restore procedure like

397
00:21:20.960 --> 00:21:24.022

on, so there's a lot more to it.

398
00:21:24.022 --> 00:21:25.800
But it's a little outside
of the Linux realm.

399
00:21:25.800 --> 00:21:29.020
So I wanted to kinda focus on the things
that were just important enough to get you

400
00:21:29.020 --> 00:21:31.350
up and running with Linux in Azure.

401
00:21:31.350 --> 00:21:35.730
And once it's there, by and large you just
treat the Linux box like any other Linux

402
00:21:35.730 --> 00:21:37.720
box and you can run backups
from inside of it if you want.

403
00:21:37.720 --> 00:21:39.620
You don't have to use
the Azure infrastructure.

404
00:21:39.620 --> 00:21:42.810
But it is there, so
it's nice to take advantage of that and

405
00:21:42.810 --> 00:21:44.420
really get your money's
worth out of Azure.

406
00:21:44.420 --> 00:21:45.275
>> Thank you very much Don,

407
00:21:45.275 --> 00:21:48.110
the great information, and
you always do a terrific job.

408
00:21:48.110 --> 00:21:51.130
And make sure you watch every
single one of the Linux

409
00:21:51.130 --> 00:21:54.990
in the Cloud series of videos
because you'll be glad you did.

410
00:21:54.990 --> 00:21:55.550
And thank you for

411
00:21:55.550 --> 00:22:00.457
watching ITProTV, remember, a good IT
pro is always learning, I'm Zach Memos.

412
00:22:00.457 --> 00:22:01.378
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

413
00:22:01.378 --> 00:22:04.173
>> And we will see you again very soon.

414
00:22:04.173 --> 00:22:10.167

00:22:10.167 --> 00:22:13.378
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

00:03:16.840 --> 00:03:20.603

00:03:20.603 --> 00:03:24.260

00:03:24.260 --> 00:03:26.043

00:03:26.043 --> 00:03:29.606

00:03:29.606 --> 00:03:30.750

00:03:32.327 --> 00:03:35.855

00:03:35.855 --> 00:03:36.414
machines.

77
00:03:36.414 --> 00:03:40.453

00:03:40.453 --> 00:03:44.037

00:03:44.037 --> 00:03:48.046

529
00:26:41.000 --> 00:26:44.620
I need to modify my grub
boot configuration.

530
00:26:44.620 --> 00:26:48.520
When the system boots up,
if it doesn't know we're doing username

531
00:26:48.520 --> 00:26:51.530
spacing at the kernel level,
then the kernel won't do it.

532
00:26:51.530 --> 00:26:54.730
It doesn't load the modules,
so this doesn't work.

533
00:26:54.730 --> 00:26:57.800
I've got to tell the kernel to do it,
so I'm gonna modify grub.

534
00:26:57.800 --> 00:27:00.782
And to do that, the easiest way
is to use the grubby command.

535
00:27:00.782 --> 00:27:02.439
If you don't have grubby,
you can install it.

536
00:27:02.439 --> 00:27:04.830
Most distros have it by default.

537
00:27:04.830 --> 00:27:09.996
So I'm gonna say grubby, and
then --args, A-R-G-S for arguments,

538
00:27:09.996 --> 00:27:15.015
equals, and I'm adding a commandline
argument to my grub boot loader.

539
00:27:15.015 --> 00:27:24.460
I'm gonna add namespace.unpriv_enable = 1,
right?

540
00:27:24.460 --> 00:27:27.500
So I'm telling it,
I wanna enable namespaces, and

541
00:27:27.500 --> 00:27:30.670
I wanna do unprivileged user mappings,
right?

542
00:27:30.670 --> 00:27:32.130
That's what I'm turning on.

543
00:27:32.130 --> 00:27:34.930
So I'm telling the kernel
when it boots up,

544
00:27:34.930 --> 00:27:38.150
understand that I might be
doing namespace remappings.

545
00:27:38.150 --> 00:27:40.430
So you're letting the kernel know.

546
00:27:40.430 --> 00:27:44.750
So when I run that, that's what's
gonna tell it, I wanna add that,

547
00:27:44.750 --> 00:27:47.690
actually I need to add a little
bit more before I stop there.

548
00:27:47.690 --> 00:27:54.859
I need to do a --update-kernel, and I need
to tell the kernel that I'm booting from.

549
00:27:54.859 --> 00:27:59.852
Now I should have gotten this before
I typed all that and I didn't, so

550
00:27:59.852 --> 00:28:03.482
let me copy this cuz I'm
gonna have to put it away.

551
00:28:03.482 --> 00:28:06.710
And I need to figure out which kernel
I'm running before I get too far.

552
00:28:06.710 --> 00:28:10.640
So let me take a look at /boot.

553
00:28:10.640 --> 00:28:11.580
There we go.

554
00:28:11.580 --> 00:28:16.570
And I am running, my latest kernel
is this guy right here, that one.

555
00:28:16.570 --> 00:28:18.110
So that's the one that I need to specify.

556
00:28:18.110 --> 00:28:20.845
So in this command, I'm gonna say, whoops,

557
00:28:20.845 --> 00:28:26.585
grubby--args=namespace.unpriv_enable=1.

558
00:28:26.585 --> 00:28:32.130
And then --update-kernel, and
I need to point to /boot/vm,

559
00:28:32.130 --> 00:28:37.670
and it's not gonna autocomplete for
me so let me copy and paste.

560
00:28:37.670 --> 00:28:40.560
And I'm gonna point to
this kernel right here.

561
00:28:40.560 --> 00:28:43.280
Now understand what that means.

562
00:28:43.280 --> 00:28:48.368
When I map to this kernel, anytime I
take an update, I've got to come in and

563
00:28:48.368 --> 00:28:51.460
re-enable the namespace, so I got to
really be paying attention to my updates.

564
00:28:51.460 --> 00:28:52.900
And on a server, we do that, right?

565
00:28:52.900 --> 00:28:54.371
So it's part of our policy, but

566
00:28:54.371 --> 00:28:57.543
it is something we need to add to
our standard procedures to specify.

567
00:28:57.543 --> 00:28:59.440
So I'm gonna go ahead and set that.

568
00:28:59.440 --> 00:29:05.190
There we go, and now what I would need
to do is reboot for that to take effect.

569
00:29:05.190 --> 00:29:08.500
And when it reboots, it's gonna recognize
that I've enabled that namespace.

570
00:29:08.500 --> 00:29:10.630
And you can always verify
it by taking a look.

571
00:29:10.630 --> 00:29:16.103
I'm gonna do a cat /proc/cmdline,
command line.

572
00:29:16.103 --> 00:29:19.519
That's gonna show me the command line
the kernel used when loading, and

573
00:29:19.519 --> 00:29:21.324
I can look in and I can see the options.

574
00:29:21.324 --> 00:29:23.564
And when I look at my kernel right now,

575
00:29:23.564 --> 00:29:26.520
I don't see any of that namespace stuff,
right?

576
00:29:26.520 --> 00:29:29.970
So I need to reboot for that to take
effect, and then I'll be able to look at

577
00:29:29.970 --> 00:29:33.605
that cmdline value, and see that it's
loaded those other options, okay?

578
00:29:33.605 --> 00:29:35.452
Now before I do that restart,

579
00:29:35.452 --> 00:29:40.100
there are a few other things that I wanna
do just to kinda get things set up, so

580
00:29:40.100 --> 00:29:42.450
even though I know it's not enabled,
I still wanna get it set up.

581
00:29:43.940 --> 00:29:48.105
By default, it's gonna create this one
namespace, this one Docker-map account.

582
00:29:48.105 --> 00:29:49.650
It's gonna map things.

583
00:29:49.650 --> 00:29:52.850
I might choose to create more
namespaces down the road, so

584
00:29:52.850 --> 00:29:55.642
I like to adjust what the maximum
namespace interval is.

585
00:29:55.642 --> 00:29:56.627
And I say I like to,

586
00:29:56.627 --> 00:30:00.911
I do it because in the Red Hat official
documentation this is what they recommend.

587
00:30:00.911 --> 00:30:04.204
And they support it so
they're people smarter than me.

588
00:30:04.204 --> 00:30:09.407
So I'm gonna increase that value, I'm

589
00:30:09.407 --> 00:30:19.064
gonna say echo
user.max_user_namespaces=15076, all right?

590
00:30:19.064 --> 00:30:23.062
That's gonna give us the ability
to have over 15,000 namespaces.

591
00:30:23.062 --> 00:30:26.014
Likely, you've only got a handful
of users, but when you start doing

592
00:30:26.014 --> 00:30:29.230
containers, you could actually have
tons of users if you're not careful.

593
00:30:29.230 --> 00:30:31.030
So we need to be able to support that.

594
00:30:31.030 --> 00:30:37.397
And I'm just gonna echo that so
that it adds into /etc/sysctl.com.

595
00:30:37.397 --> 00:30:40.390
If I'm appending it to that file and
adding that option.

596
00:30:40.390 --> 00:30:44.894
So again, when we reboot, it'll read that
file and it'll create enough room for

597
00:30:44.894 --> 00:30:46.880
that many namespaces, all right?

598
00:30:46.880 --> 00:30:49.180
Then the user accounts.

599
00:30:49.180 --> 00:30:51.050
I need to map the ID number.

600
00:30:51.050 --> 00:30:52.200
And there's a risk.

601
00:30:52.200 --> 00:30:56.043
When it creates the ID number,
it could overlap with an existing user.

602
00:30:56.043 --> 00:30:57.290
I don't want that.

603
00:30:57.290 --> 00:31:00.084
So I'm gonna pick a number that's
like way out in left field so

604
00:31:00.084 --> 00:31:03.550
that I don't have to worry about it
bumping into my existing user accounts.

605
00:31:03.550 --> 00:31:07.200
So I'm gonna say echo dockermap, right?

606
00:31:07.200 --> 00:31:12.963
That's the user account that it's gonna
create is dockermap:999999, all right?

607
00:31:12.963 --> 00:31:15.240
I'm picking a really high number, right?

608
00:31:15.240 --> 00:31:19.870
Remember in most distros, your users
start at 1,000, some they start at 500.

609
00:31:19.870 --> 00:31:22.741
So 999,000, that should give me
a lot of grow room right there.

610
00:31:22.741 --> 00:31:24.196
>> That's good.

611
00:31:24.196 --> 00:31:26.641
>> And then I'll say :1000, right?

612
00:31:26.641 --> 00:31:32.207
Because the root user inside
the container will be ID 1000,

613
00:31:32.207 --> 00:31:36.961
and I'm gonna pipe that into /etc/subuid,
right?

614
00:31:36.961 --> 00:31:40.102
Subuid is from the namespace,
what's powering that.

615
00:31:40.102 --> 00:31:44.678
And then I'm gonna do the same thing but
for subgid.

616
00:31:44.678 --> 00:31:48.312
Because remember, when we create a user
account they get a user ID and a group, so

617
00:31:48.312 --> 00:31:51.426
if I create a dpezet user,
there's a dpezet user and a dpezet group.

618
00:31:51.426 --> 00:31:54.457
Here I'm doing the same thing for
Docker-map.

619
00:31:54.457 --> 00:31:57.523
Right, so
I'm getting that kind of put in place.

620
00:31:57.523 --> 00:32:01.170
Let's see, at that point,
I've already made my kernel change.

621
00:32:01.170 --> 00:32:04.770
I've already updated the config file.

622
00:32:04.770 --> 00:32:07.770
Everything is good at this
point except rebooting.

623
00:32:07.770 --> 00:32:12.320
So I need to reboot my server and once it
reboots, now the name mapping will be in

624
00:32:12.320 --> 00:32:16.260
place and I'll be able to create
containers and know that they are secure.

625
00:32:16.260 --> 00:32:17.400
This is a lot of work, right?

626
00:32:17.400 --> 00:32:21.310
A lot of moving parts here to get
this configured, but from a security

627
00:32:21.310 --> 00:32:24.505
standpoint, if this is a production
server, that's really important thing.

628
00:32:24.505 --> 00:32:26.414
>> Hm.
>> So this is probably the longest answer

629
00:32:26.414 --> 00:32:27.877
to a short question,
>> [LAUGH]

630
00:32:27.877 --> 00:32:29.102
>> Zack had asked the question if we're

631
00:32:29.102 --> 00:32:29.938
ready to do containers.

632
00:32:29.938 --> 00:32:34.156
If I was on a test or a development
machine, if I was on my own laptop,

633
00:32:34.156 --> 00:32:36.890
I was done ten minutes ago, right.

634
00:32:36.890 --> 00:32:39.940
And we were done and we could have got
this up and going with the default.

635
00:32:39.940 --> 00:32:44.638
But on a production server you need to go
a little further to get that security.

636
00:32:44.638 --> 00:32:47.981
And this is where DevOps is such
a challenge because, is it right to

637
00:32:47.981 --> 00:32:51.980
expect the developer to know to go
through and do all this name mapping?

638
00:32:51.980 --> 00:32:53.040
I don't think so.

639
00:32:53.040 --> 00:32:55.250
Most server admins don't
know to do this stuff.

640
00:32:55.250 --> 00:32:59.390
So it's important that we get it taken
care of on our infrastructure and

641
00:32:59.390 --> 00:33:01.930
then we let the developers develop,
that's what they're great at.

642
00:33:01.930 --> 00:33:06.050
Or we let the server admins be server
admins, that's what they're great at.

643
00:33:06.050 --> 00:33:08.430
Blending things can create risk but

644
00:33:08.430 --> 00:33:11.340
doing what I just did helps
to minimize that risk.

645
00:33:11.340 --> 00:33:16.129
To say if I give you root access
in a container, you can go crazy.

646
00:33:16.129 --> 00:33:20.000
But you're held inside of that container
and if you escape out into the underlying

647
00:33:20.000 --> 00:33:22.590
host, doesn't matter
you're not rooted anymore.

648
00:33:22.590 --> 00:33:24.910
Now you're just mapped
to this doc map account.

649
00:33:24.910 --> 00:33:28.020
You're just a regular unprivileged user
that we don't have to worry about you

650
00:33:28.020 --> 00:33:28.660
doing any damage.

651
00:33:28.660 --> 00:33:31.850
So now we've reached the point where

652
00:33:31.850 --> 00:33:33.862
I'm comfortable with
the production machine, right.

653
00:33:33.862 --> 00:33:37.510
We've got the Docker service up and
running, I can start throwing

654
00:33:37.510 --> 00:33:40.350
the containers in it and
giving people access to those containers.

655
00:33:40.350 --> 00:33:42.070
It's up, it's in business.

656
00:33:42.070 --> 00:33:44.320
And now, we're to use it.

657
00:33:44.320 --> 00:33:46.777
>> Great teaching Don in
Linux as a Docker host.

658
00:33:46.777 --> 00:33:48.860
Any last words and we move on?

659

point that I didn't actually create

a container after all of that.

Well I need to reboot for

663
00:33:59.795 --> 00:34:01.973
>> So this is Linux as a Docker host,
look for

664

Linux as a Docker container I think

How we can use it,

We'll get a chance to see all that,

00:34:16.730 --> 00:34:19.080

But here we focused on

>> Thank you.

in the background.

509
00:26:20.740 --> 00:26:23.180
So if I were take a look at
what's kinda sitting here.

510
00:26:23.180 --> 00:26:28.080
If I do a docker ps,
docker ps shows me the active containers.

511
00:26:28.080 --> 00:26:31.110
Well, I don't have any active containers,
cuz every one I've run,

512
00:26:31.110 --> 00:26:34.240
I've done something and
I've gotten out of it, exited it, right?

513
00:26:34.240 --> 00:26:36.810
So every container in this show so
far has been closed.

514
00:26:36.810 --> 00:26:40.790
If you do a docker ps -a though,
I can see that I've actually left

515
00:26:40.790 --> 00:26:45.090
behind a whole trail of
just junked up containers.

516
00:26:46.120 --> 00:26:47.970
Some of them that I launched and
just ran a command.

517
00:26:47.970 --> 00:26:49.963
So here I can see this one,
I launched CentOS.

518
00:26:49.963 --> 00:26:54.910
I ran uname -a, I did it about a minute
ago and it's just sitting there now.

519
00:26:54.910 --> 00:26:59.320
Okay, if I leave this, eventually
we'll purge them out of here, and

520
00:26:59.320 --> 00:27:01.080
I lose those changes right?

521
00:27:01.080 --> 00:27:05.781
But if I built one up as a web server and
I wanted to keep it as a web server.

522
00:27:05.781 --> 00:27:09.511
And I wanted to turn that into my own
custom base image, then that's the next

523
00:27:09.511 --> 00:27:13.340
thing I would need to do is take that
customized container and save it.

524
00:27:13.340 --> 00:27:17.598
Save it to my own base image, so now I can
spin up web servers whenever I want it and

525
00:27:17.598 --> 00:27:18.816
have that available.

526
00:27:18.816 --> 00:27:20.832
Okay, now I wanna show you
guys how to do that, but

527
00:27:20.832 --> 00:27:22.427
I know I'm low on time on this episode.

528
00:27:22.427 --> 00:27:24.440
So Zach, why don't we go into a part two?

529
00:27:24.440 --> 00:27:25.521
>> We need a part two.

530
00:27:25.521 --> 00:27:26.485
>> And in this episode,

531
00:27:26.485 --> 00:27:28.956
we did get a chance to see how
to spin up the containers.

532
00:27:28.956 --> 00:27:32.903
How to pull the images down, how to kinda
start to work with them in the basic form.

533
00:27:32.903 --> 00:27:34.357
But in the next episode,

534
00:27:34.357 --> 00:27:39.010
I'm gonna show you guys how to customize
the container to build a custom image.

535
00:27:39.010 --> 00:27:42.790
An image that has your specifications,
and then we'll actually do Apache.

536
00:27:42.790 --> 00:27:45.090
We'll launch a web server
inside of a container,

537
00:27:45.090 --> 00:27:47.020
kind of show how we can containerize that.

538
00:27:47.020 --> 00:27:50.020
So if you ever need a quick on demand web
server, you can do it in a container.

539
00:27:50.020 --> 00:27:52.630
Instead of having to install
a web server on your own machine,

540
00:27:52.630 --> 00:27:56.610
which increases your attack surface and
puts you at risk, so it's a great example.

541
00:27:56.610 --> 00:27:59.450
So that's all the stuff that
we'll be able to see in part two.

542
00:27:59.450 --> 00:28:01.070
>> And I'm excited,
I want to find out more.

543
00:28:01.070 --> 00:28:03.490
Linux as a Docker container
part two will be coming up.

544
00:28:03.490 --> 00:28:04.400
This has been part one,

545
00:28:04.400 --> 00:28:07.530
but before we move on I know, I can sense-
>> [LAUGH]

546
00:28:07.530 --> 00:28:09.070
>> You have a few more words for us.

547
00:28:09.070 --> 00:28:12.140
>> Everything I've done so far,
I've been doing on a CentOS machine,

548
00:28:12.140 --> 00:28:14.520
which means it works the same on Red Hat.

549
00:28:14.520 --> 00:28:18.860
But this actually does work the same
on Fedora, on Ubuntu, on Debian.

550
00:28:18.860 --> 00:28:20.731
Docker is designed to be independent.

551
00:28:20.731 --> 00:28:22.027
So once you install the packages,

552
00:28:22.027 --> 00:28:24.632
all the commands we've done works
the same on each of the platforms.

553
00:28:24.632 --> 00:28:26.450
So fortunately, there's that.

554
00:28:26.450 --> 00:28:29.380
So just be aware that it's not
a very difficult thing to support,

555
00:28:29.380 --> 00:28:30.420
regardless of what the host is.

556
00:28:30.420 --> 00:28:32.670
That's kinda the advantage of Docker.

557
00:28:32.670 --> 00:28:34.170
>> Thank you, Don, you do an awesome job.

558
00:28:34.170 --> 00:28:37.050
And make sure to watch every single
episode of Linux and the Cloud,

559
00:28:37.050 --> 00:28:38.346
you'll be glad that you did.

560
00:28:38.346 --> 00:28:40.549
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

561
00:28:40.549 --> 00:28:43.978
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

562
00:28:43.978 --> 00:28:44.718
I'm Zach Memos.

563
00:28:44.718 --> 00:28:45.471
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

564
00:28:45.471 --> 00:28:48.430
>> And we will see you again very soon.

565
00:28:48.430 --> 00:28:54.247
[MUSIC]

566
00:28:54.247 --> 00:28:57.208
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue looking at linux as a Docker container, saving changes, running a container in the background, if we normally run the containers interactively, how to clean up the containers we no longer need, stopping a container, and deleting a container.
episodes.title: Linux as a Docker Container Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.437
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.437 --> 00:00:06.294
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.294 --> 00:00:08.280
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.280 --> 00:00:11.910
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.910 --> 00:00:14.393
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:14.393 --> 00:00:16.300
Helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.300 --> 00:00:20.400
I'm your host Zach Memos as we
continue on with Linux in the clouds.

8
00:00:20.400 --> 00:00:23.106
And Linux as a docker container part two.

9
00:00:23.106 --> 00:00:27.778
We had part one, and now we get the rest
of it from Don Pezet who knows what's up.

10
00:00:27.778 --> 00:00:29.790
>> [LAUGH]
>> He know [INAUDIBLE].

11
00:00:29.790 --> 00:00:31.206
>> All right, Zack,
let's continue our adventure, right?

12
00:00:31.206 --> 00:00:32.876
>> [LAUGH]
>> At the end of part two or

13
00:00:32.876 --> 00:00:35.680
at the end of part one,
I guess we're just making part two.

14
00:00:35.680 --> 00:00:39.050
But [LAUGH] in the last episode,
we created a bunch of containers.

15
00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:41.130
>> Yes, we did.
>> But they're all very temporary, right?

16
00:00:41.130 --> 00:00:44.360
And so after I was done with them,
we kinda just casting them aside and

17
00:00:44.360 --> 00:00:47.150
leaving behind a whole trail of
containers left on my machine now.

18
00:00:47.150 --> 00:00:50.670
But basically, we need to just start
thinking a little more long term, right?

19
00:00:50.670 --> 00:00:53.600
How can we actually use these
containers in production?

20
00:00:53.600 --> 00:00:57.380
So in this episode, I wanna take the stuff
we covered in the first episode and

21
00:00:57.380 --> 00:01:00.460
I wanna change that to make it a little
more like what we would actually do

22
00:01:00.460 --> 00:01:02.590
in a production world to
get this stuff deployed.

23
00:01:02.590 --> 00:01:05.292
So that's what we're gonna take a little
look at right here in this episode.

24
00:01:05.292 --> 00:01:09.540
>> Yeah, at the end of episode one,
we were closing down these containers.

25
00:01:09.540 --> 00:01:12.780
We weren't being able to save anything,
so is there a way to save them?

26
00:01:12.780 --> 00:01:14.310
>> Right, so there is.

27
00:01:14.310 --> 00:01:17.720
The idea on this is that containers
are designed to be temporary.

28
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:20.090
You launch them,
they do a job and they get out.

29
00:01:20.090 --> 00:01:24.000
Or maybe you launch one, it's doing
the job and it gets too busy and so

30
00:01:24.000 --> 00:01:25.200
you launch a second one, or

31
00:01:25.200 --> 00:01:29.000
a third one, or another thousand of them
to really be able to pick up that load.

32
00:01:29.000 --> 00:01:32.780
That's how containers are designed to
be able to scale very big, very fast.

33
00:01:32.780 --> 00:01:37.930
So when I create a container,
it needs to already know what its job is.

34
00:01:37.930 --> 00:01:41.080
And that means the base images that
I was working with in the last

35
00:01:41.080 --> 00:01:42.470
episode are not good enough.

36
00:01:42.470 --> 00:01:47.430
We need to go in and customize those base
images and change them, modify them,

37
00:01:47.430 --> 00:01:50.080
make them work the way
we want them to work.

38
00:01:50.080 --> 00:01:53.250
And it usually is a matter of
installing some software, right?

39
00:01:53.250 --> 00:02:00.539
So if I spin up a container,
I'll do a docker run -it centos, right?

40
00:02:00.539 --> 00:02:03.600
So I'm gonna spin up a centos container,
right?

41
00:02:03.600 --> 00:02:07.160
And I'm gonna grab this id while I've
got it here, just so I don't forget it,

42
00:02:07.160 --> 00:02:09.480
cuz it's not something that
I can really remember.

43
00:02:09.480 --> 00:02:13.470
And it assigns a little code name
to each container you spin up to,

44
00:02:13.470 --> 00:02:14.780
it just doesn't show you right here.

45
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:16.440
So we'll see that in the minute.

46
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:20.110
But now that I'm in here,
I can do a yum update if I need to, or

47
00:02:20.110 --> 00:02:23.960
a yum install httpd maybe
I want php as well, right?

48
00:02:23.960 --> 00:02:27.740
So I can provide it the different
things that I need to get installed

49
00:02:27.740 --> 00:02:30.250
to get this one configured
the way that I want.

50
00:02:30.250 --> 00:02:33.150
And once I've got that stuff installed,
then I can go and create my index.html,

51
00:02:33.150 --> 00:02:36.150
and all of the other things
that I need inside of it.

52
00:02:36.150 --> 00:02:42.730
Now my container doesn't have a firewall,
so it doesn't have firewalld or iptables.

53
00:02:42.730 --> 00:02:45.500
It doesn't have a lot of the other
stuff embedded in it that we

54
00:02:45.500 --> 00:02:47.030
would normally have to worry about.

55
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:49.370
Now, my container doesn't have
things like a firewall, right?

56
00:02:49.370 --> 00:02:51.560
I don't have firewalld or iptables.

57
00:02:51.560 --> 00:02:55.290
So a lot of my configuration is much more
simple than it would be in a normal.

58
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:59.080
And so I don't have to worry about
configuring that kinda security side.

59
00:02:59.080 --> 00:03:01.787
I do need to forget my index.html.

60
00:03:01.787 --> 00:03:04.700
I do need to create the things
that Apache needs to run.

61
00:03:04.700 --> 00:03:06.940
It's got its own configuration
file I might need to customize or

62
00:03:06.940 --> 00:03:08.390
SSL certificates, right?

63
00:03:08.390 --> 00:03:10.460
So I need to get all that
stuff loaded in there and

64
00:03:10.460 --> 00:03:11.980
configure it the way that I want.

65
00:03:11.980 --> 00:03:14.690
But now this is finished at a minimum,

66
00:03:14.690 --> 00:03:18.550
I've got a base installed
of Apache with php.

67
00:03:18.550 --> 00:03:20.650
And assuming that Apache is running,

68
00:03:20.650 --> 00:03:24.440
I should be able to browse this container
and see the Apache test page, right?

69
00:03:24.440 --> 00:03:26.340
Test page should come up and
that is what I should get.

70
00:03:26.340 --> 00:03:30.850
So, at this stage, I would customize this
container exactly how I want, right?

71
00:03:30.850 --> 00:03:33.860
Do everything that we need to
do to get that container working

72
00:03:33.860 --> 00:03:34.410
the way that we want.

73
00:03:34.410 --> 00:03:36.640
All right, after that we exit.

74
00:03:36.640 --> 00:03:39.510
And when we exit,
that closes the container.

75
00:03:39.510 --> 00:03:41.470
And I know I said earlier that
it doesn't save the changes.

76
00:03:41.470 --> 00:03:43.966
And that's not technically true.

77
00:03:43.966 --> 00:03:47.730
It saved the changes but
just for this one container.

78
00:03:47.730 --> 00:03:51.020
And this one container is no longer
running so effectively it's gone, right?

79
00:03:51.020 --> 00:03:52.620
But it's not actually gone.

80
00:03:52.620 --> 00:03:58.910
If I do a docker ps -a, I can find
that container still sitting there.

81
00:03:58.910 --> 00:03:59.869
Here it is, right?

82
00:03:59.869 --> 00:04:02.079
And here is where I see
that kind of nickname and

83
00:04:02.079 --> 00:04:03.842
this one was called jovial murdock.

84
00:04:03.842 --> 00:04:06.195
>> [LAUGH]
>> It does the adjective noun for

85
00:04:06.195 --> 00:04:07.020
everything.

86
00:04:07.020 --> 00:04:09.680
So you got grave newton and
clever heisenberg and so on.

87
00:04:09.680 --> 00:04:11.860
Each one is getting a nickname.

88
00:04:11.860 --> 00:04:14.840
And you can actually modify these
machines based on their nickname.

89
00:04:14.840 --> 00:04:18.440
Sometimes it's easier to remember but
I've got the id right on my screen so

90
00:04:18.440 --> 00:04:19.470
that's easier for me.

91
00:04:19.470 --> 00:04:21.060
>> Good.
>> I can see that it's exited and

92
00:04:21.060 --> 00:04:22.070
I can see that it's sitting here.

93
00:04:22.070 --> 00:04:26.053
And the last thing that was running was
/bin/bash, right, cuz I did an interactive

94
00:04:26.053 --> 00:04:28.834
terminal so that's what it's
got kind of fire it up for me.

95
00:04:28.834 --> 00:04:35.420
But I wanna take this id and I wanna
convert it into my own base image, right?

96
00:04:35.420 --> 00:04:39.026
So I can come in and say, docker commit.

97
00:04:39.026 --> 00:04:44.150
Docker commit is how we save this and
turn it into a base image.

98
00:04:44.150 --> 00:04:48.525
So right now when I look at my base image,
I can say docker images and

99
00:04:48.525 --> 00:04:51.690
I've got these default ones
that I got from docker.io.

100
00:04:51.690 --> 00:04:53.560
I got a Ubuntu, CentOS, Debian.

101
00:04:53.560 --> 00:04:56.250
I used the CentOS latest
to build this one.

102
00:04:56.250 --> 00:04:58.586
And I can say docker commit.

103
00:04:58.586 --> 00:05:02.910
And then I can tell it a description
if I want to assign one.

104
00:05:02.910 --> 00:05:06.099
So this is a CentOS Web Server.

105
00:05:06.099 --> 00:05:08.160
Right, so that will be my description.

106
00:05:08.160 --> 00:05:09.670
I can put an author if I want.

107
00:05:09.670 --> 00:05:11.520
These are optional but
it's kind of nice to have them so

108
00:05:11.520 --> 00:05:13.852
I'll put that I am the author.

109
00:05:13.852 --> 00:05:18.470
All right, and then I need to tell the
container id which fortunately I copied,

110
00:05:18.470 --> 00:05:19.980
so I can paste it right in there.

111
00:05:19.980 --> 00:05:23.530
So there's the container id that
I'm gonna use to build this image.

112
00:05:23.530 --> 00:05:28.310
And then I need to give it an image name
and I'm just going to call mine webserver.

113
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:32.390
Right, because that's what this is it's a
CentOS image that's running a web server.

114
00:05:32.390 --> 00:05:33.800
So I'm gonna do that.

115
00:05:33.800 --> 00:05:37.870
And when I run that,
it's building a new base image.

116
00:05:37.870 --> 00:05:40.820
And then I get the SHA256
checksum right there.

117
00:05:40.820 --> 00:05:44.330
And if run docker images, in addition to

118
00:05:44.330 --> 00:05:49.490
all the images that I pulled from docker
io, I now have a new one right here.

119
00:05:49.490 --> 00:05:53.377
I have an image called webserver and this
is the latest version of it cuz I like

120
00:05:53.377 --> 00:05:55.401
spend up new version this time goes on.

121
00:05:55.401 --> 00:05:59.500
It's got a new image id,
and it's 340 megs in size,

122
00:05:59.500 --> 00:06:03.030
it's bigger than all of the other guys.

123
00:06:03.030 --> 00:06:04.060
Why is that?

124
00:06:04.060 --> 00:06:04.838
Because I install software.

125
00:06:04.838 --> 00:06:06.445
>> [LAUGH]
>> I install Apache, and

126
00:06:06.445 --> 00:06:09.418
php, and all there dependent library so
it made big grow, so

127
00:06:09.418 --> 00:06:12.117
it's larger as you add more and
more data inside of it.

128
00:06:12.117 --> 00:06:17.781
But now I've got that base image and
anytime I want to,

129
00:06:17.781 --> 00:06:23.076
I can launch a new container
off of this base image,

130
00:06:23.076 --> 00:06:26.908
I can say docker run- it webserver.

131
00:06:26.908 --> 00:06:30.803
And now I'm gonna launch a new
container based off of my image and

132
00:06:30.803 --> 00:06:34.195
when that runs if I do like
a I'm going to install httpd,

133
00:06:34.195 --> 00:06:39.050
I'll find that it' already installed and
already at the latest version.

134
00:06:39.050 --> 00:06:43.046
It's already setup the way that I want
to and it's got exactly what I need.

135
00:06:43.046 --> 00:06:46.311
So when I launch that interactive shell,
now I'm not starting with just the basic

136
00:06:46.311 --> 00:06:49.980
system anymore, now I"m starting with
the modified image that we created.

137
00:06:49.980 --> 00:06:52.790
>> Well, do we normally run
the containers interactively?

138
00:06:52.790 --> 00:06:53.600
>> So we don't right?

139
00:06:53.600 --> 00:06:55.610
So now that I've got this
thing set up as a web server,

140
00:06:55.610 --> 00:06:58.950
I don't normally log back into
the terminal again ever really right?

141
00:06:58.950 --> 00:07:01.520
So from here on out, it's a web server.

142
00:07:01.520 --> 00:07:04.100
And so I would just fire up Apache.

143
00:07:04.100 --> 00:07:06.990
I would tell that to run as opposed
to getting interactive like this.

144
00:07:06.990 --> 00:07:08.550
So let me show you how you would do that.

145
00:07:08.550 --> 00:07:13.495
We say docker run, and
instead of -it, right, which is i for

146
00:07:13.495 --> 00:07:17.966
interactive, t for a pseudo tty,
a virtual terminal,

147
00:07:17.966 --> 00:07:22.649
I'm going to tell it docker run -d,
-d means detached.

148
00:07:22.649 --> 00:07:24.927
In other words,
don't attached it to my user session,

149
00:07:24.927 --> 00:07:27.500
I want you to run this container and
stick it in the background.

150
00:07:27.500 --> 00:07:30.160
In my mind, I always think d for
demon like a service.

151
00:07:30.160 --> 00:07:31.160
>> That's what I was thinking.

152
00:07:31.160 --> 00:07:32.510
>> But it's actually detached, right?

153
00:07:32.510 --> 00:07:34.350
So it's detached from my console.

154
00:07:34.350 --> 00:07:39.220
So I'm gonna say docker run -d and
then I'm wanna run a web server.

155
00:07:39.220 --> 00:07:43.615
So I would say, I'm gonna give it
the image that I want to use which is

156
00:07:43.615 --> 00:07:49.270
webserver and then I need to tell
it the command that I want to run.

157
00:07:49.270 --> 00:07:55.458
And I want to run /user/sbin/httpd,
all right.

158
00:07:55.458 --> 00:08:00.225
So Im running that particular command and
if you run httpd by itself,

159
00:08:00.225 --> 00:08:03.480
it just runs and
then closes and that's it.

160
00:08:03.480 --> 00:08:10.330
So I need to tell it to
run as a FOREGROUND task.

161
00:08:10.330 --> 00:08:14.400
And so Apache has this command
line argument of -D, capital, and

162
00:08:14.400 --> 00:08:16.030
then FOREGROUND in all capital.

163
00:08:16.030 --> 00:08:18.550
And that says,
I want you to run not as a demon,

164

not as a service in the background but
